{{Twelvers|collapsed=1}} {{Lead too short|date=September 2016}} Criticism of [[Twelver]] [[Shia Islam]] dates from the initial rift between the two primary denominations of Islam, the [[Sunni]] and the [[Shia Islam|Shia]]. The question of succession to [[Muhammad in Islam|Muhammad]], the nature of the [[Imamate (Twelver doctrine)|Imamate]], the status of the [[Muhammad al-Mahdi|twelfth Shia Imam]], and other areas in which Shia Islam differ from Sunni Islam have been criticized by Sunni scholars, even though there is no disagreement between the two regarding the centrality of the [[Quran]], [[Muhammad]], and many other doctrinal, theological and ritual matters.<ref>{{harvnb|Momen|1985|p=xiii}}</ref> Shiite commentators such as [[Musa al-Musawi]] and [[Ali Shariati]] have themselves, in their attempts to reform the faith, criticized practices and beliefs which have become prevalent in the Shiite community.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Brunner|editor1-first=Rainer|editor2-last=Ende|editor2-first=Werner|title=The Twelver Shia in Modern Times: Religious Culture and Political History|date=2001|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004118034|page=178|quote=The intellectual history of Twelver Shia Islam in the 20th century has witnessed quite a few attempts by religious scholars and lay intellectuals at religious reform, which nearly inevitably meant criticism of existing practices. The reformers have concentrated on various aspects of Shia popular religion with a high symbolic value which determine the outward appearance of Shia Islam and its relation to mainstream Sunni Islam. Not least because of that strong symbolism they have deemed these practices to be against the true spirit of Shia Islam, even against the spirit of Islam itself.}}<!--|accessdate=1 July 2014--></ref> <!-- ==Holy sites== ==Praying to the Imams== ==Prominence of Imams over Muhammad== -->
==Image veneration== [[File:Shia Imams in Isfahan Bazaar.JPG|thumb|Common representations of some Imams.]] {{Further|Aniconism in Islam}} Sunnis are particularly critical of the "love of visual imagery evident in Shia popular devotionalism" and regularly cite this characteristic (often referred to as '[[Shia iconography]]')<ref>{{cite book|author1=David Gardner|title=Last Chance: The Middle East in the Balance|date=18 Dec 2011|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857730336|edition=revised|quote=...is profoundly repellent to the orthodox Sunni. So too are the rituals associated with the Imam Hussein - comparable to the central event of the crucifixion in Christianity - and indeed the whole Shia iconography, which for the Sunni strays into idol-worship.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Ingvild Flaskerud|title=Visualizing Belief and Piety in Iranian Shiism|date=2 Dec 2010|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=9781441149077|page=234|edition=illustrated}}</ref> as proof of Shia deviance or heresy.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Vali Nasr|title=The Shia Revival: How Conflicts within Islam Will Shape the Future|date=17 Apr 2007|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|isbn=9780393066401|page=44}}</ref>
==The Occultation== {{main|Ghaybah}} In the tradition of Twelver Shia Islam, the twelfth and final Shia Imam, [[Muhammad al-Mahdi]], who is also considered by Twelver Shia to be the prophesied redeemer of Islam known as the [[Mahdi]], went into [[Ghaybah|''ghaybah'' ("occultation")]] in 873. However, this belief has long been criticized by Sunni scholars who “often speculate that the twelfth Imam never existed, but was a myth designed to keep the Shia cause alive.”<ref>The Routledge Handbook of Religion and Security, by Chris Seiple, Dennis R. Hoover, Pauletta Otis, 2012, page 60</ref> Meanwhile, western scholars have also cast doubt upon the existence of an occulted Imam. According to Robert Gleave, the occultation of the 12th Imam “became subsequent orthodox doctrine” after none of the competing theories that sought to explain the succession to a childless [[Hasan al-Askari|11th Imam]] “seemed satisfactory”.<ref>A Companion To The History Of The Middle East, edited by Youssef M.Choueiri, page 93</ref> According to [[Bernard Lewis]], the occultation and subsequent return of the Imam became a characteristic Shia doctrine following the “suppression of many risings and the disappearance of their leaders”; where the leader disappears and “his followers say that he is not dead; he has gone into concealment”. With each new leader “who disappeared and did not return”, this belief was “enriched” and became more detailed and “essential” as a “feature of Shia Islam.”<ref>Islam and the West, by Bernard Lewis, 1993, page 163</ref> [[File:MasjideJamkaran.jpeg|thumb|[[Jamkaran]], supposed site of a historical appearance of al-Mahdi.]] However, according to [[Wilferd Madelung]] in [[Encyclopedia of Islam]], the doctrine of the Occultation was well-documented by traditions of the Imams before the occultation of the Twelfth Imam whom the majority of the Imamiyya came to consider as the Mahdi after the death of the eleventh. As an example he mentions that "the pattern was already set in regard to [[Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyyah|Muḥammad b. al-Ḥanafiyya]], whose death was denied by the Kaysāniyya [q.v.]. They believed that he was hidden in the mountains of Raḍwā and would return to rule the world. Similar beliefs arose around Muḥammad b. al-Ḥanafiyya’s son [[Abu Hashim|Abū Hashim]]"<ref>[http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopaedia-of-islam-2/al-mahdi-COM_0618 al-Mahdī. Encyclopaedia of Islam, Second Edition. Brill Online, 2012. Reference. University of Southern California. 18 June 2012]</ref> Moreover, Madelung names several Sunni scholars who have similar beliefs.<ref>{{cite book|quote=Testimony in support of the Mahdīship of the Twelfth Imām by these Sunnī authors, as also of later ones like the Mālikī scholar Ibn al-Ṣabbāg̲h̲ al-Isfāḳusī al-Makkī (d. 855/1451), a [[Maghreb|Mag̲h̲ribī]] resident in Mecca, and, more recently, the Ḥanafī [[Naqshbandi|Naḳs̲h̲bandī]] S̲h̲ayk̲h̲ Sulaymān b. Ibrāhīm al-Ḳundūzī al-Balk̲h̲ī (d. 1294/1877 in Istanbul), was regularly noted by Imāmī apologists. The works of al-Gand̲j̲i and Kamāl al-Dīn Ibn Ṭalḥa were extensively quoted already by ʿAlī b. ʿĪsā al-Irbilī (d. 692/1293) in his Kas̲h̲f al-g̲h̲umma fī maʿrifat al-aʾimma, which in turn won positive comment from Sunnī authors because of its extensive reliance on Sunnī sources. Further support for the Mahdīship of the Twelfth Imām came from Ṣūfī circles. Already [[Al-Bayhaqi|Abū Bakr al-Bayhaḳī]] (d. 458/1066) had noted that some Ṣūfī [[Gnosticism|gnostics]] (d̲j̲amāʿa min ahl al-kas̲h̲f) agreed with the Imāmī doctrine about the identity of the Mahdī and his g̲h̲ayba. The Persian Ṣūfī Ṣadr al-Dīn Ibrāhīm al-Ḥammūyī (late 7th/13th century) supported Imāmī doctrine on the Mahdī in his Farāʾid al-simṭayn. The Egyptian Ṣūfī al-S̲h̲aʿrānī, while generally showing no sympathy for S̲h̲īʿism. affirmed in his al-Yawāḳīt wa ’l-d̲j̲awāhir (written in 958/1551) that the Mahdīwas a son of Imām al-Ḥasan al-ʿAskarī born in the year 255/869 and would remain alive until his meeting with Jesus. His advent could be expected after the year 1030/1621. He based his assertion on the testimony of the Ṣūfī S̲h̲ayk̲h̲ Ḥasan al-ʿIrāḳī, who claimed to have met the Mahdī, and on a spurious quotation from [[Ibn Arabi|Ibn al-ʿArabī’s]] al-Futūḥāt al-Makkiyya identifying the Expected Mahdī with the Twelfth Imām. This quotation of Ibn al-ʿArabī was noted and accepted by both Imāmī and Sunnī scholars. The Egyptian S̲h̲ayk̲h̲ al-Ṣabbān (d. 1206/1792), in his Isʿāf al-rāg̲h̲ibīn fī sīrat al-Muṣṭafā wa-faḍāʾil ahl baytih al-ṭāhirīn, censured Ibn al-ʿArabī for supporting such a view against the clear evidence of the traditions accepted by Sunnī scholars.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}}}}</ref> In a [[Hadith]] upon whose authenticity Shiites and Sunnis agree, [[Muhammad]] had said, "If there were to remain in the life of the world but one day, God would prolong that day until He sends in it a man from my community and my household. His name will be the same as my name. He will fill the earth with equity and justice as it was filled with oppression and tyranny." {{efn| For more hadiths see Sahih of Tirmidhi. Cairo, 1350-52. vol. IX, chapter "Ma ja a fi’l-huda": Sahih of Abu Da’ud, vol.ll, Kitab al-Mahdi: Sahih oflbn Majah, vol.ll. chapter khurui’ al-Mahdi": Yanabi’ al-mawaddah: Kitab al-bayan fi akhbar Sahib al zaman of Kanji Shaafi’i, Najaf, 1380; Nur al-absar: Mishkat almasabih of Muham. mad ibn ’Abdallan al-Khatib. Damascus, 1380; al- Sawa’iq al-muhriqah, Is’af al raghibin of Muhammad al-Sabban, Cairo. 1281: al-Fusul al-muhimmmah; Sahih of Muslim: Kitab al-ghaybah by Muhammad ibn Ibrahim al-Nu’mani, Tehran, 1318; Kamal al-din by Shaykh Saduq. Tehran, 1301; lthbat al-hudat; Bihar al-anwar, vol. LI and LII. }}<ref name=Tabatabai /><ref name="al Fusul al Muhimmah">{{cite book|last1=Ibn Masud|first1=Abdallah|title=al Fusul al Muhimmah|page=271}}</ref><ref name="al Fusul al Muhimmah"/> However, the majority of Sunnis do not consider the son of [[Hasan al-Askari|eleventh Imam]] as the promised [[Mahdi]]. Shias claim the only possible occasion that the son of eleventh Imam is said to have made a public appearance was at the time of his death, then as a child the boy was seen no more.<ref name=Tabatabai>{{cite book|last1=Tabatabai|first1=Sayyid Muhammad Hossein|title=Shi'ite Islam|date=1975|publisher=State University of New York Press|isbn=0-87395-272-3|pages=210–211 (185–186 in the ebook)|edition=First|url=http://islamicbookbank.org/Files/21d1af68-b0c1-4e28-8b42-1f97feac88b0.pdf}}</ref><ref name="al Fusul al Muhimmah"/> His birth, Shiite says, like the case of the prophet [[Moses]], was concealed due to the difficulties of the time, and because of the belief that he was the promised [[Muhammad al-Mahdi]], the caliphs of the time had decided definitely to put an end to the Imamate in Shiism once and for all.<ref name="Donaldson">{{cite book|last=Donaldson|first=Dwight M.|title=The Shi'ite Religion: A History of Islam in Persia and Irak|year=1933|pp=190–197,217–222|publisher=BURLEIGH PRESS}}</ref>
== Usuli versus Akhbari == Twelvers of the [[Akhbari]] and [[Usuli]] branches have for centuries debated over the interpretation of religious texts and the responsibilities of Twelver scholars in the absence of the [[Hujjat al-Mahdi|Hidden 12th Imam]]. This culminated during the latter half of the 18th century with the violent suppression of Akhbari’s, especially under the direction of Usuli scholar [[Muhammad Baqir Behbahani]].<ref>''Philosophers and Religious Leaders'', edited by Christian D. Von Dehsen & Scott L. Harris, page 29</ref><ref>Cole, J. R. I. ''Roots of North Indian Shi'ism in Iran and Iraq: Religion and State in Awadh'', 1722-1859. Berkeley: University of California Press, pages 33 & 164</ref><ref>''The New Encyclopedia of Islam'', by Cyril Glassé, page 35</ref>
On the one hand, Akhbaris (nowadays a small minority) reject the use of reasoning in deriving religious laws and verdicts. They believe the Qur'an and Sunnah (traditions of Muhammad and the Imams) provide all the laws necessary for their followers, and that reasoning is open to errors from imperfect scholars in the absence of an infallible Imam. They also criticise what they see as [[Akhbari#History|the transgressions of Twelver scholars]], in gradually acquiring for themselves the powers and responsibilities of the Hidden Imam. Some Akhbaris have reported their belief this was, among others explanations, a result of the greed for power and wealth of Usuli scholars over laymen.<ref>{{cite book|title=Roots of North Indian Shi'ism in Iran and Iraq: Religion and State in Awadh|year=1989|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=978-0520056411|pages=165–166|author=J. R. I. Cole|chapter=3.6}}</ref>
On the other hand, Usulis criticise the rigidity and narrow-mindedness of the Akhbaris and interpret the religious texts and take on much of the roles of the 12th Imam in accordance with the naturally evolving requirements of the Twelver Shia community.
==Nikah mut‘ah== [[Nikah mut‘ah]] (lit. "pleasure marriage"), is a fixed-term marriage practiced in Twelver Shia Islam. The duration of this type of marriage is fixed at its inception and is then automatically dissolved upon completion of its term. For this reason, nikah mut‘ah has been widely criticised as the religious cover and legalization of [[prostitution]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/6714885.stm Iran talks up temporary marriages], by [[Frances Harrison]], BBC News, Last Updated: 2 June 2007.</ref><ref>[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/01/19/AR2007011901850.html Temporary 'Enjoyment Marriages' In Vogue Again With Some Iraqis], by Nancy Trejos, The Washington Post, 20 January 2007.</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=f1CzcNX-nVgC&pg=PA6&dq=temporary+marriage+prostitution&hl=en#v=onepage&q&f=false Law of desire: temporary marriage in Shi'i Iran], by Shahla Haeri, pg.6.</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=zPXu561ZpvgC&pg=PT192&dq=temporary+marriage+prostitution&hl=en#v=onepage&q=false Islam For Dummies], by Malcolm Clark.</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=Lq2fxfbb0i4C&pg=PT85&dq=temporary+marriage+prostitution&hl=en#v=onepage&q=false Islam: a very short introduction], by [[Malise Ruthven]].</ref> The [[Christian]] [[missionary]] [[Thomas Patrick Hughes]] criticized Mut'ah as allowing the continuation of "one of the abominable practices of ancient Arabia." <ref>"In permitting these usufructuary marriages Muḥammad appears but to have given Divine (?) sanction to one of the abominable practices of ancient Arabia, for Burckhardt (vol. ii. p. 378) says, it was a custom of their forefathers to assign to a traveller who became their guest for the night, some female of the family, most commonly the host’s own wife!" [[Thomas Patrick Hughes|Hughes, T. P.]] (1885). In A Dictionary of Islam: Being a Cyclopædia of the Doctrines, Rites, Ceremonies, and Customs, together with the Technical and Theological Terms, of the Muhammadan Religion. London: W. H. Allen & Co.</ref> The majority of Sunni scholars and Western writers have called it prostitution. Julie Parshall,<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title = Lifting the Veil: The World of Muslim Women|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=JKqkohMVPVsC|publisher = InterVarsity Press|date = 2003-04-01|isbn = 9780830856961|first = Philip L.|last = Parshall|first2 = Julie|last2 = Parshall}}</ref> Zeyno Baran,<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title = Citizen Islam: The Future of Muslim Integration in the West|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=hfdGAQAAQBAJ|publisher = A&C Black|date = 2011-07-21|isbn = 9781441112484|first = Zeyno|last = Baran}}</ref> and Elena Andreeva<ref>Andreeva, Elena (2007). Russia and Iran in the great game: travelogues and Orientalism. Routledge studies in Middle Eastern history. 8. Psychology Press. pp. 162–163. {{ISBN|0415771536}}. "Most of the travelers describe the Shi'i institution of temporary marriage (sigheh) as 'legalized profligacy' and hardly distinguish between temporary marriage and prostitution."</ref> have written that this kind of marriage is prostitution. According to Shahla Haeri, in Iran the middle class itself considers it to be prostitution which has been given a religious cover by the fundamentalist authorities.<ref name=":3">Haeri, Shahla (1989). Law of desire: temporary marriage in Shi'i Iran. Contemporary issues in the Middle East. Syracuse University Press. p. x. {{ISBN|0815624832}}. "Outside of the religious establishment and the ongoing disputes between Shi'i and Sunni scholars, the attitude toward temporary marriage has been primarily one of ambivalence and disdain. Before the revolution of 1979, the secular Iranian middle classes dismissed temporary marriage as a form of prostitution that had been legitimized by the religious establishment, who, to use a popular Persian expression, 'put a religious hat on it.'"</ref>
Nikah mut‘ah was practiced at the time of [[Muhammad]] and [[Abu Bakr]], but was outlawed by the second Caliph, [[Umar ibn Khattab]]. Therefore, it is forbidden among Sunnis, but Shia consider Umar's account as legally and religiously invalid, as they argue it's legitimated by Quran 4:24.<ref name=Iranica>[http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/mota Temporary marriage, ''Encyclopedia Iranica'']</ref><ref>Michel Foucault, ''Discipline and punish: The birth of Prison, Trans Alan Sheridan'' (New York: Vantage, 1979)</ref><ref name=Friedl>[[Mahnaz Afkhami]], Erika Friedl - 1994 In the eye of the storm: women in post-revolutionary Iran - Page 105</ref> Shia have systematically contested the criticism that it is a cover for prostitution, and argue their rationales regarding the legal uniqueness of temporary marriage, which distinguishes Mut'ah ideologically from prostitution.<ref name=Iranica/><ref>[http://www.al-islam.org/al-serat/muta/ Sachiko Murata, ''Temporary Marriage in Islamic Law'']</ref> Children born of temporary marriages are considered legitimate, and have equal status in law with their siblings born of permanent marriages, and do inherit from both parents. Women must observe a period of celibacy ([[idda]]) to allow for the identification of a child’s legitimate father, and a woman can only be married to one person at a time, be it temporary or permanent. Some Shia scholars also view Mut'ah as a means of eradicating prostitution from society.<ref>Said Amir Arjomand (1984), ''From nationalism to revolutionary Islam'', page 171</ref>
==Taqiyya (dissimulation)== ''[[Taqiyya]]'' is a Shia practice under which it is permissible to hide one's faith in order to preserve life. The Shia have been criticised for this practice, an act deemed against the virtues of bravery and courage.<ref name= Shiite>Muḥammad Ḥusayn Ṭabāṭabāʼī, Muhammad H. Al-Tabataba'i. ''Shiʻite Islam''. Issue 5 of The Persian studies series. SUNY Press, 1977. {{ISBN|0-87395-390-8}}, {{ISBN|978-0-87395-390-0}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=Be5DeNM8d1EC&pg=PA224&dq=criticize+shiism&hl=en&ei=yg73TLCZFsKB8gaj7YWGBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDkQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q&f=false Pg 227]</ref> Critics argue that the Twelvers have taken dissimulation far beyond life-threatening situations and have allowed its use in any scenario that is judged to benefit the continuation or propagation of the Twelver creed, as is emphasized by the "celebrated" reputed saying of the 6th Imam [[Ja'far al-Sadiq]], “[t]aqiyyah is my religion and the religion of my forefathers”;<ref>{{cite web|title=Islamic Government: Governance of the Jurist|url=http://www.al-islam.org/islamic-government-governance-of-jurist-imam-khomeini/program-establishment-islamic-government#footnote32_sq22h47|accessdate=22 April 2014|author=Ruhollah Khomeini|authorlink=Ruhollah Khomeini|location=Program for the Establishment of an Islamic Government}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Mirage in Iran|date=1985|publisher=Tawheed Publications|location=Shi'ism:The Present|page=35|url=http://www.islamicresearchacademy.com/uploads/8/6/3/7/863702/the_mirage_in_iran_comp.pdf|author=Ahmad al-Afghaanee|editor=[[Bilal Philips]]|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref> along with his other often quoted saying from [[Kitab al-Kafi]]: "Nine tenths of faith is taqiyya."<ref>{{cite book|last=Crone|first=Patricia|title=Medieval Islamic Political Thought|date=2005|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|location=The Imamis|isbn=9780748621941|pages=123–124|authorlink=Patricia Crone}}<!--|accessdate=22 April 2014--></ref><ref>{{cite book|title=The Divine Guide in Early Shi'ism: The Sources of Esotericism in Islam|date=1994|publisher=SUNY Press|isbn=9780791421222|page=129|author=Mohammad Ali Amir-Moezzi}}<!--|accessdate=22 April 2014--></ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Shia & Sunni perspective on Islam: an objective comparison of the Shia and Sunni doctrines based on the Holy Quran and Hadith|date=4 May 2007|publisher=The University of California|page=90|author=Ahmad Abdullah Salamah|accessdate=22 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Secrecy and Concealment: Studies in the History of Mediterranean and Near Eastern Religions|date=1995|publisher=BRILL|location=Taqiyya in Shia Theology and Religion|isbn=9789004102354|page=373|editor=Hans Gerhard Kippenberg, Guy G. Stroumsa}}<!--|accessdate=22 April 2014--></ref> The practice is widely criticized by Sunni Muslims as indicative of the problems that they face when interacting with Shi'ites.<ref>{{cite book|author1=A. Christian Van Gorder|title=Christianity in Persia and the Status of Non-muslims in Iran|date=2010|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9780739136096|page=102|edition=illustrated}}<!--|accessdate=28 September 2015--></ref> According to [[Patricia Crone]], Twelvers even extended the use of taqiyya “to protect their secret wisdom from exposure to the uncomprehending masses (including their own co-religionists), who might pervert it or denounce it as heretical."<ref>{{cite book|last=Crone|first=Patricia|title=Medieval Islamic Political Thought|date=2005|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|location=The Imamis|isbn=9780748621941|page=124|authorlink=Patricia Crone}}<!--|accessdate=22 April 2014--></ref> This view has been supported by Faysal Noor in his book ''Taqiyyah: The Other Face.'' <ref>{{cite book|title=Taqiyyah: The Other Face|date=2013|publisher=Al-Munasaha |url=http://twelvershia.net/2014/05/29/1184/|author=Faysal Noor|editor=[[Hani al-Tarabulsi]]}}</ref>
Living as a minority among the Sunni majority, however, made such a doctrine important to Shiite.Besides, the practice of concealing one's beliefs in dangerous circumstances originates in the [[Qur'an]], which deems blameless those who disguise their beliefs in such cases.<ref>{{Cite quran|16|106|style=ref}}</ref><ref>{{harvnb|Momen|1985|p=183}}</ref> The practice of taqiyya in difficult circumstances is considered legitimate by [[Muslims]] of various sects. Sunni and Shia commentators alike observe that verse {{Cite quran|16|106}} refers to the case of [[Ammar ibn Yasir|'Ammar b. Yasir]], who was forced to renounce his beliefs under physical duress and torture.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Ismailis in the Middle Ages: A History of Survival, a Search for Salvation|isbn=978-0-19-531173-0|first=Shafique N.|last=Virani|authorlink=Shafique Virani|year=2007|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|location=New York|page=48}}</ref> This practice was emphasized in Shia Islam whereby adherents may conceal their religion when they are under threat, [[Persecution of Muslims|persecution]], or compulsion.<ref>[http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/browse?_hi=0&_startPrefix=taqiya&jumppage.x=13&jumppage.y=8 "Taqiyah"]. ''Oxford Dictionary of Islam''. John L. Esposito, Ed. Oxford University Press. 2003. Retrieved 25 May 2011.</ref> Taqiyya was developed to protect Shia who were usually in minority and under pressure. In the Shia view, taqiyya is lawful in situations where there is overwhelming danger of loss of life or property and where no danger to religion would occur thereby.<ref name=Momen>{{cite book|last=Momen|first=Moojan|authorlink= Moojan Momen |title=An Introduction to Shi'i Islam|year=1985|publisher=Yale University Press|pages=39, 150–183|isbn=978-0-300-03531-5}}</ref> Shia commentators have argued that taqiyya has precedents from the time of [[Muhammad]], including the story of [[Ammar ibn Yasir]], Such commentators argue that to not avoid certain death is illogical, and that dissimulation is permissible under various circumstances, such as to preserve life, to protect the chastity of women, or avoid destitution.<ref name= Shiite/>
==Disrespect to Abu Bakr, Umar and Uthman== One allegation commonly leveled against the Twelvers is that they disrespect the Sunni Caliphs [[Abu Bakr]], [[Umar]] and [[Uthman]] who supported [[Mohammad]] as per Sunni belief<ref>Nicholas Schmidle. ''To Live Or to Perish Forever: Two Tumultuous Years in Pakistan''. Macmillan, 2010. {{ISBN|0-8050-9149-1}}, {{ISBN|978-0-8050-9149-6}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=LayUUE4KNtwC&pg=PA23&dq=Shia+curse+sahaba&hl=en&ei=O57_TI7DKMys8Ab9qcXcBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=cursing&f=false Pg 23]</ref> during the early days of Islam but later turned enemies of [[Mohammad|Mohammad's]] household ([[Ahl al Bayt]]) as per Shia belief.<ref>The History of al-Tabari, Volume IX, The Last Years of the Prophet, p186-187, SUNY Press</ref> Such Shia practices include the recited [[Dua Sanamain Quraish]], which calls God's curse on the first two Sunni caliphs following Muhammad's death, [[Abu Bakr]] and [[Umar]]. Following the [[Safavid]] empire's conversion to the Shia sect of Islam, the first three caliphs, whom the Shia felt usurped Ali's right to be caliph, were cursed during Friday sermons.<ref>Patrick Cockburn. ''Muqtada: Muqtada al-Sadr, the Shia revival, and the struggle for Iraq''. Simon and Schuster, 2008. {{ISBN|1-4165-5147-6}}, {{ISBN|978-1-4165-5147-8}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=cZBUaEQmhRwC&pg=PA25&dq=Shia+curse+abu+bakr&hl=en&ei=dZ3_TI2hO8KclgfZ8pinCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CDYQ6AEwAw#v=onepage&q=cursed&f=false Pg 25]</ref>
As Sunni scholar Shaykh [[Saleh Al-Fawzan]] summarises the views of the [[Rafidi]]s as compared to the [[Nasibi]]s:
:''The Raafidis are the opposite: they love the Prophet's family (ahl al-bayt) - or so they claim, but they hate the Saahaaba, whom they curse, denounce as kaafirs, and criticize.''<ref>Muhammad Saed Abdul-Rahman. ''Islam: Questions and Answers - Schools of Thought, Religions and Sects, Volume 8''. MSA Publication Limited, 2003. {{ISBN|1-86179-291-3}}, {{ISBN|978-1-86179-291-4}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=xcPwGmYwCKUC&pg=PA102&hl=en&ei=mhP3TOfxL8P68AafkNW8Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEIQ6AEwBjgo#v=onepage&q&f=false Pg 102]</ref>
During the 1960s, when an incipient ecumenical movement called for the unification of Shia and Sunni Islam, religious writers cited this "disrespect" for the [[Sahabah]] as a barrier to unification. In 1980s and 1990s, three major religious writers in [[Egypt]], [[Saudi Arabia]], and [[Pakistan]] again cited this argument, noting that until all "profanity" against the Sahabah was abandoned, dialogue with Shia scholars could not begin.<ref name=Iranand>Jamal S. Suwaidi. ''Iran and the Gulf: a search for stability''. I.B.Tauris, 1996. {{ISBN|1-86064-144-X}}, 9781860641442. [https://books.google.com/books?id=w_swDoVoYxcC&pg=PA165&dq=criticism+shi'a&hl=en&ei=mLj2TKCwF4L68AaPnsS4BQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CD4Q6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=criticism%20shi'a&f=false Pg 165]</ref>
In 2010, [[Ali Khamenei]] issued a [[fatwa]] which bans any insult to the [[Sahabah]] (companions of Muhammad) as well as Muhammad's wives. The fatwa was issued in an effort to reconcile legal, social, and political disagreements between Sunni and Shia.<ref>{{cite web|title=World Shia Leader Ali Khamenei Fatwa on Insulting Sahaba [R.A]|url=http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x17asqe_world-shia-leader-ali-khamenei-fatwa-on-insulting-sahaba-r-a_news|website=Dailymotion}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Imam Khamenei: Insulting Symbols of Sunni Brothers Forbidden|url=http://www.rohama.org/en/news/2940/imam-khamenei-insulting-symbols-of-sunni-brothers-forbidden|website=Rohama}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aimislam.com/al-azhar-chancellor-religious-leaders-hail-ayatollah-khameneis-fatwa/ |title=Al-Azhar Chancellor, Religious Leaders Hail Ayatollah Khamenei's Fatwa | AhlulBayt Islamic Mission (AIM) |publisher=Aimislam.com |date=4 October 2010 |accessdate=1 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140101080029/http://www.aimislam.com/al-azhar-chancellor-religious-leaders-hail-ayatollah-khameneis-fatwa/ |archivedate=1 January 2014 |df= }}</ref> The same{{citation needed|date=April 2017}} fatwas were issued from [[Ali al-Sistani]] and other{{who|date=April 2017}} Shiite [[Marja']].<ref>{{cite web|title=Shiite leaders forbid insults against Sunnis|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2015/01/iran-iraq-fatwa-sunni-shiite-insults.html#|website=Almonitor}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Grand Ayatullah Sistani Issues Fatwa condemning Abuse Against Sunni Sanctities in the Light of teaching of 12 Imams|url=http://jafrianews.com/2013/10/14/ayatullah-sistani-issues-fatwa-condemning-abuse-against-sunni-sanctities-in-the-light-of-teaching-of-12-imams/|website=Jafria News}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Insulting the Sahaba Runs against Teachings of Ahl-ul-Bayt (AS) |url=http://ijtihad.ir/NewsDetailsen.aspx?itemid=3231|website=Ijtehad.ir}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sayyid Sistani's Fatwa about the Prophet (S.A.W.A.)'s Companions|url=http://www.imam-us.org/fatwa/companions}}</ref>
However, other Shia scholars such as [[Shaykh Tusi]],<ref>Abu Ja'far al Tusi wrote in his book "al Iqtisad", page 36: "Ayesha was adamant upon waging war against Ali (as), and she did not repent. This proves her kufr and her remaining on it."</ref> [[Muhammad Baqir Majlisi]],<ref>Allamah Baqir Majlisi wrote in [[Bihar al-Anwar]], volume 22, page 233: ( "Allah (swt) says in Qur'an [Allah has cited for the kuffar the example of the wife of NuH and the wife of LuT.] (66:10), I (i.e. Allamah Baqir Majlisi) declare: It is not a secret for the discerning critic (reader/observer) and the one who is clever and knowledgeable that what is mentioned in these verses is an exposure, in fact an explicit declaration of the hypocrisy of [[Aisha]] and [[Hafsa bint Umar|Hafsah]] as well as their kufr (disbelief)."</ref> [[Sadiq Hussaini Shirazi]], [[Abu al-Qasim al-Khoei]], [[Hossein Vahid Khorasani]],<ref>On 24th Jumada Al-Awwal 1438 AH (which coincided with 22nd February 2016), Grand Ayatollah Sheikh Wahid Al-Khorasani said that Abu Bakr and Umar took the land of Fadak from Fatima unjustly, and so they have no right being buried in the house of the Holy Prophet, as "it is usurped land". In the presence of hundreds of scholars, students of knowledge, and believers, then went on to say: "It is therefore the duty of every single Muslim now to dig up the graves of these two men (i.e. Abu Bakr and Umar), and to exhume what remains of their corpses. In fact, the ruling of burial in usurped property is the obligation of exhumation according to legal consensus. This is the principle and this is the conclusion." See: [http://wahidkhorasani.com/فارسی/اخبار/محتوا/359_تذکر%20صریح%20معظم%20له%20به%20کسانی%20که%20سخنان%20ایشان%20را%20تحریف%20کرده%20اند].</ref> [[Ruhollah Khomeini]],<ref>Kitab al-Taharah Volume 3 Page 457: As for the other groups of the Nawasib, actually the Khawarij, even though they’ll get more punished than the Kuffar, yet this is not proving them to be Najis (impure). Hence, if a ruler makes Khurooj (opposes/fights) Amir Al-Mu’mineen (as) not for religious reason, rather for worldly reason (seeking power) or other motives like A'isha, Zubair, Talha, Mu’aawiya and their likes, or if someone holds Nasb/enmity towards him or one of the [twelve] Imams (as), not due to religious reason rather because of his enmity towards the Quraish, or Bani Hashim or the Arabs or because [Ali] killed one of his children or his father etc. Apparently none of those are necessarily considered Najis (impure) from an apparent point of view, in fact they are more impure than dogs and pigs. See: [https://sonsofsunnah.files.wordpress.com/2011/09/post-5632-0-69180000-1314764662_thumb.jpg]</ref> [[Mohammad Jamil Hammoud al-Amili]],<ref>On his official website, the Grand Ayatollah "reaffirmed" the Shia belief that "Aisha commited zina". See: [http://www.aletra.org/subject.php?id=22]</ref> [[Yasser Al-Habib]], cursed and/or allow(ed) for disrespecting of the figures revered by the Sunnis, on the grounds that religious truth can't be compromised in the name of a false unity.
==Mourning Husayn and self-flagellation during Ashura== [[File:Annual_ritual_observed_on_the_10th_day_of_Muharram_in_Al_Manama_Bahrain.jpg|thumb|Tatbir during [[Mourning of Muharram|Moharram]], [[Bahrain]], 2011]] Twelvers have been criticised for the practice of ''[[Tatbir]]'' (a form of [[self-flagellation]]) during [[Day of Ashura|Ashura]], the observation of the martyrdom of [[Husayn ibn Ali|Husayn]] traditionally accompanied by acts of ritual self-harm, which is often described as barbaric.<ref>{{cite book|title=Thinking of Answers: Questions in the Philosophy of Everyday Life|date=1 Mar 2010|publisher=Bloomsbury Publishing|isbn=9781408810538|author=A.C. Grayling|chapter=Drugs and Laws|quote=Sunni Muslims and even some Shiites are opposed to the Ashura ritual, condemning it as barbaric.}}<!--|accessdate=29 April 2014--></ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Azeri Women in Transition: Women in Soviet and Post-Soviet Azerbaijan|date=5 Mar 2014|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136871702|page=195|author=Dr Farideh Heyat Nfa|quote=Later, during the 1920s, there were intense public campaigns by the Soviet government against the rituals of Ashura, denounced as barbaric practices, and a vestige of feudalism.}}<!--|accessdate=29 April 2014--></ref>
The practice is contested among Shi'a clerics: while traditionalist clerics allow believers to indulge in Tatbir, modernist clerics deem it not to be permissible because it is considered as self-damage and haram in Islam.<ref name="MonsuttiNaef2007">{{cite book|last1=Monsutti|first1=Alessandro|last2=Naef|first2=Silvia|last3=Sabahi|first3=Farian|title=The Other Shiites: From the Mediterranean to Central Asia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_62A00tLaygC&pg=PA146|year=2007|publisher=Peter Lang|isbn=978-3-03911-289-0|pages=146–}}</ref> Suffering and cutting the body with knives or chains was banned by the Shiite [[List of current Maraji|marja]] [[Ali Khamenei]], Supreme Leader of [[Iran]] and by [[Hezbollah]] in Lebanon.<ref name="Edith Szanto 2012">Edith Szanto, “Sayyida Zaynab in the State of Exception: Shi‘i Sainthood as ‘Qualified Life’ in Contemporary Syria,” International Journal of Middle East Studies 44 no. 2 (2012): 285-299.</ref> Khamenei issued a fatwa on 14 June 1994 banning this practice. He considered it irreligious and not suitable for good Muslims.<ref name=Iranand/>
According to Salafi Sunni scholars such as [[Ibn Taymiyyah]] and [[Abd al-Aziz ibn Baz]], the celebration of Ashura is itself a blatant and primary example of the propensity of the Shia to indulge in ''[[Bid‘ah]]'' (religious innovation). They argue that the annual mourning occasion for Husayn (or any other individual) was never instituted or practiced by Muhammad—not even for his closest family members—and hence has no validity in Islam.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Raihan Ismail|title=The Saudi Ulema and the Shi'a of Saudi Arabia|journal=Journal of Shi'a Islamic Studies|date=Autumn 2012|volume=5|issue=4|page=418}}</ref><ref>''Iqtida' as-Sirat al-Mustaqim'' (Following The Straight Path), by [[Ibn Taymiyyah]], p. 300-301.</ref><ref>''[[Minhaj as-Sunnah an-Nabawiyyah]]'', by [[Ibn Taymiyyah]], vol. 4, p. 554-556.</ref><ref>''Fataawa al-Shaykh ‘Abd al-‘Azeez ibn Baaz'' (8/320).</ref> Likewise, [[Ibn Rajab]] in his ''Kitab al-Iata'if'' argued against Ashura: "Neither God..., nor His Messenger...have ordered that days on which prophets met with calamities and the day of their death be instituted as a day of mourning. How much more is this true for a person lesser than they?"<ref>{{cite book|author1=N. J. G. Kaptein|title=Muḥammad's Birthday Festival: Early History in the Central Muslim Lands and Development in the Muslim West Until the 10th/16th Century|date=1993|publisher=BRILL|isbn=9789004094529|pages=57–8}}</ref>
==Child Imams== Three of the [[The Twelve Imams|Twelve Imams]], held by the Shia to be God's representatives on Earth, were less than ten years old when they assumed the undisputed and exclusive leadership of the Twelver Shia community. The 9th Imam, [[Muhammad al-Taqi]], was 7 and a half years old at the time he assumed the Imamate; the 10th Imam, [[Ali al-Hadi]], was between 6.5 and 8.5 years, and the 12th and final Imam, [[Muhammad al-Mahdi]], was 4 and a half years old. Pakistani Islamic scholar and polemicist [[Ehsan Elahi Zaheer]] argues against the possibility of these personalities assuming the leadership of the [[Imamah (Shi'a Twelver doctrine)|Imamate]] at such young ages.<ref>[http://www.kr-hcy.com/shia/books/ehsanzaheer/index.shtml ''Shia's and Shiaism, there Genesis and Evolution: Shia Sects''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228185246/http://www.kr-hcy.com/shia/books/ehsanzaheer/index.shtml |date=2013-12-28 }}, by Allama Ehsan Elahi Zaheer. Text quotation: "''If God had commanded us to obey an adolescent, He would have also ordered the adolescent to obey His injunctions. Just as it is unlawful to declare a non-adult as "Mukallaf", similarly he is not legally empowered to arbitrate among people. He can not grasp the subtleties and intricacies involved in the solution of problems; he is not fully conversant with religious injunctions and the rules and regulations of Sharia. The Sharia introduced by the holy Prophet (peace be upon him) which is the basic need of the Ummah till the arrival of the doomsday is obviously beyond the range of an adolescent's comprehension. If a non-adolescent can handle these complicated and sensitive issues, then we can also excpet a child who is in his cradle and swings to the rhythms and melodies of nursery rhymes, to show an awareness of these issues and to suggest solutions to dis-entangle their knots. But it all sounds absurd because adolescence is not the same things as non-adolescence and a child can not rationally be expected to behave like a grown-up person. The perceptions and reflections of the former do not operate at the same wave lengts as those of the latter.''"</ref> [[Wilferd Madelung]] notes, however, that in Shia belief the knowledge of an Imam comes from "inspiration, not acquisition", and thus that even a young Imam is not considered unprepared, receiving revelation upon the death of his predecessor.<ref>An Ismaili heresiography, by [[Wilferd Madelung]], Paul Ernest Walker, [https://books.google.com/books?id=yvGtIQQ_v7QC&printsec=frontcover&dq=An+Ismaili+heresiography,+by+Wilferd+Madelung,&hl=en&ei=f4D7TMu1JtDoOYz82dQK&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=book-thumbnail&resnum=1&ved=0CCkQ6wEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false pg.114-115]</ref>
Shias further claim that [[Muhammad al-Jawad|ninth Imam]] the Shiite could not help asking from his father, the [[Ali al-Ridha|eighth Imam]] whether a child at that age could take on such a responsibility if something happened to Imam [[Ali al-Ridha]]; and al-Ridha used to illustrate the story of the Jesus who was even younger when he had become the prophet of his time however Sunnis state ascribing prophetic values to Shia Imams is another example of Shirk.{{efn|[http://tanzil.net/#5:110 Quran, 5:110]}}<ref name="Donaldson" /><ref>{{cite book|last=Sharif al-Qarashi|first= Bāqir|year=2005|title=The Life of Imam Muhammad Al-Jawad|others=Translated by Abdullah al-Shahin|location=Qum|publisher=Ansariyan Publications|pp=53,205–206}}</ref> [[John the Baptist]] was also a child when he was given wisdom. His reading and understanding of the scriptures, surpassed even that of the greatest scholars of the time.{{efn|[http://tanzil.net/#19:12 Quran, 19:12]}}<ref name="ReferenceB">''A–Z of Prophets in Islam and Judaism'', B. M. Wheeler, ''John the Baptist''</ref>
Shias claim that the Shiite account of [[al-Ma'mun]]'s first meeting with [[Muhammad al-Jawad]] shows that wisdom is given to the Twelve Imams.{{efn|Once when al-Ma'mun was out hunting with his hunting birds he passed through a road where boys were playing. Among them was Muhammad al-Jawad. When al-Ma'mun's horsemen approached the boys ran away except al-Jawad who remained there. Noting this al-Ma'mun stopped his carriage and asked, "Boy, what kept you from running away with the others?" Al-Jawad replied, "The road was not so narrow that I should fear there would not be room for you to pass, and I have not been guilty of any offence that I should be afraid, and I considered that you were the sort of man who would not injure one who had done no wrong." The [[Caliphate|Caliph]] was very delighted, after he had gone on a short distance one of his hunting birds brought him a small fish, which he hid in his fist and returned and asked the boy, who was still standing there "What have I in my hand?" The young Imam answered that the "creator of living things has created in the sea a small fish that is fished by the falcons of the kings and caliphs to try with it the progeny of [[Muhammad|al-Mustafa]].<ref name="Donaldson"/> Al-Ma'mun was much pleased and asked the child about his lineage, to which Imam al-Jawad responded accordingly.}} After which the Caliph called together a great gathering in which all kinds of questions were asked from the young Imam, who astonished them all with his judgment and learning. Then al-Ma'mun declared formally that he gave him his daughter in marriage thereby.<ref name="Donaldson"/>
Other criticisms include the fact that Imamah is not mentioned in the Quran and the absence of such a crucial pillar in Shia Islam brings into question the validity of such claims. The Twelver Imamah doctrine is not shared by the majority of Sunni Muslims. The Syrian mufti [[Ibn Taymiyyah]] (d. 728 AH/1328 AD) composed a long refutation of it in his ''[[Minhaj as-Sunnah an-Nabawiyyah]]''.<ref>See "Ibn Taymiyya’s Critique of Shia Imamology. Translation of Three Sections of his "Minhāj al-Sunna", by Yahya Michot, ''The Muslim World'', 104/1-2 (2014), pp. 109-149.</ref>
==Infallibility of Imams== Twelver Shi'ism has been criticized for exaggerating the holiness and infallibility of its Imams. Al-Kulayni in al-Kafi claims that the Imams know when they die and they do not die unless by their own choice, they know everything in the past and in the future and every time when God informs Muhammad, He orders him to inform Ali too. In ''Islamic Government'' Khomeini writes: "Amongst the necessities in our doctrine is that our Imams have a dignity which no favored angel nor sent prophet could ever reach. As it has been narrated, the Imams were lights under the shadow of the throne before creating this world”.<ref>I. M. N. Al-Jubouri. Islamic Thought. page 314</ref> According to critics this purity is close to that of the prophet Muhammad, if not quite on the same level, and reflects excessiveness of view.<ref>I. M. N. Al-Jubouri. Islamic Thought.[https://books.google.com/books?id=owqY-90imMIC&printsec=frontcover&dq=islamic+thought+al-jubouri&hl=en&sa=X&ei=UqK4T-yLKYOWhQevxPT9CA&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=islamic%20thought%20al-jubouri&f=false page 107]</ref> Shia Islam has been criticised for magnifying the role of the Imams alongside, or even above, that of Muhammad.<ref>{{cite web|author1=SHMUEL BAR|title=Sunnis and Shiites—Between Rapprochement and Conflict|url=https://hudson.org/content/researchattachments/attachment/1370/bar_vol2.pdf|accessdate=19 May 2015|page=91}}</ref><ref>M. F.Sayeed. Fundamental doctrine of Islam and its pragmatism.[https://books.google.com/books?id=QWi-KN_OFcMC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Fundamental+doctrine+of+Islam+and+its+pragmatism&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_aK4T_elCdOLhQeEht2BCQ&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Fundamental%20doctrine%20of%20Islam%20and%20its%20pragmatism&f=false page 298]</ref>
Both Shiite and Sunni are in agreement over the two functions of prophet hood: to reveal God's law to men, and to guide men toward God. However, while Sunnis believe that both have come to an end with the death of [[Muhammad]], Shiites believe that whereas legislation ended, the function of guiding and "explaining divine law continued through the line of Imams."<ref>{{harvnb|Momen|1985|p=147}}</ref> In Shiite theology, thus, God does not guide via authoritative texts (i.e. the Qur'an and Hadith) only but also guides through some specially equipped individuals known as Imams.<ref name="Brown">{{cite book|last1=Brown|first1=Daniel|title=Rethinking Tradition in Modern Islamic Thought|date=1999|publisher=Cambridge University Press|p=60|isbn=978-0-521-65394-7|edition=1st}}</ref> This constitution, Shiite says, is not limited to Islam, but each great messenger of God had two covenants, one concerning the next prophet who would eventually come, and one regarding the immediate successor, the Imam.<ref name="Momen"/> For example, Sam was an imam for [[Noah in Islam|Noah]], [[Ishmael]] was an Imam for [[Abraham]], [[Aaron]] or [[Joshua]] for Moses, Simon, John and all the disciples for Jesus, and [[Ali]] and his descendants for [[Muhammad]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Amir-Moezzi|first1=Mohammad Ali|title=SHIʿITE DOCTRINE|url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/shiite-doctrine|website=Encyclopedia Iranica}}</ref> It is narrated from the sixth imam, [[Ja'far al-Sadiq]] who had said "where there to remain on the earth but two men, one of them would be the proof of God".<ref>{{harvnb|Momen|1985|p=148}}</ref> The difference between apostles (Rasuls), the prophets(Nabi) and the Imams, thus, is described as follows: Rasul sees and hears the angel in awakness and sleep. Nabi hears the angel and sees him while asleep, but does not see him while awake though hears the speech. Imam (muhaddith) is the one who hears the angel in awakness while does not see him in awakness or sleep.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Ahlul Bayt Digital Islamic Library Project Team|title=A Shi'ite Encyclopedia|url=http://www.al-islam.org/shiite-encyclopedia-ahlul-bayt-dilp-team}}</ref> According to Shiite, the status and authority attributed to Imams will be senseless if they are prone to the same weakness found in general people.<ref name="Brown"/> God must assign someone similar to prophet in his attributes and [[Ismah]] as his successor to guide the people and to interpret the [[Quran]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Dabashi | first=Hamid |pp=103–104| authorlink=Hamid Dabashi | title= Theology of Discontent: The Ideological Foundation of the Islamic Revolution in Iran| publisher=Transaction Publishers | year=2006 | isbn=1-4128-0516-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Tabatabaei|first1=Muhammad Husayn|title=Islamic Teachings in Brief|date=2008|publisher=Ansariyan Publications|url=http://www.al-islam.org/islamic-teachings-in-brief-allamah-tabatabai}}</ref> Shias claim their sources state that the [[Ahl al-Bayt]] which are described pure of sin in the verse of purification are [[Ahl al-Kisa]] involved only specific members of the Prophet's family,{{efn|According to Madelung the majority of the Sunnite reports quoted by al-Tabari do not identify the ahl al-Kisa. Other Sunnite reports mention Fatimah, Hasan and Husayn, and some agree with the Shiite tradition that the ahl al-kisa including Ali, were assembled for the [[Event of Mubahala]].<ref name="Madelung1998"/>}}<ref name="Madelung1998">{{cite book|last=Madelung|first=Wilferd|title=The Succession to Muhammad: A Study of the Early Caliphate|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2QKBUwBUWWkC|date=15 October 1998|p=16|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-64696-3}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=[[Muhammad ibn Jarir al-Tabari]]|title=[[Tafsir al-Tabari]] vol. XXII|pages=5–7}}</ref><ref name="Rizvi">{{cite book|last1=Rizvi|first1=Sayyid Muhammad|title=The Infallibility of the Prophets in the Qur'an|date=2001|pp=15–16|publisher=Bilal Muslim Mission of Tanzania|url=http://www.al-islam.org/ismat-infallibiity-of-prophets-in-the-Qur'an-sayyid-muhammad-rizvi}}</ref> and Shis claim this as an argument for their infallibility.<ref name="Rizvi"/>
==Fatimah's divine revelations== According to some Twelver Shia scholars, Muhammad's daughter [[Fatimah]] received divine revelations after her father's death. During the 75 days that Fatimah had contact and communication with Gabriel, her husband Ali wrote down and recorded the revelations that were made to Fatimah which she dictated to him, to form the [[Book of Fatimah]].<ref>[http://www.al-shia.org/html/eng/books/hadith/al-kafi/part4/part4-ch40.htm Kitab Al-Kafi, Chapter 40 (Statements about al-Jafr, al-Jami‘ and the Book of Fatima (a.s.))] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720165047/http://www.al-shia.org/html/eng/books/hadith/al-kafi/part4/part4-ch40.htm |date=July 20, 2011 }}, H 639, Ch. 40, h 5, translated by Muhammad Sarwar. A sound [[Hadith|tradition]] according to Grand Ayatollah [[Ruhollah Khomeini|Khomeini]] in: “THE POSITION OF WOMEN FROM THE VIEWPOINT OF IMAM KHOMEINI”, pg.10-11. This tradition quotes Imam [[Ja'far al-Sadiq]], as saying: “After the death of her father, Fatima, upon whom be peace, lived for 75 days. She was in this world and she was overcome with grief. Gabriel, the Trusted Spirit, came to her regularly to console her and tell her of future events.”</ref>
Sunnis argue that [[Fatimah]] never received divine revelations from Allah.<ref>Thomas Patrick Hughes. ''Dictionary of Islam: being a cyclopædia of the doctrines, rites, ceremonies, and customs, together with the technical and theological terms, of the Muhammadan religion''. W. H. Allen, 1885. [https://books.google.com/books?id=rDtbAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA573&dq=sunnis+deny+revelation+fatimah&hl=en&ei=qr72TKSHHIG78gabn6y5Bw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCMQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q&f=false Pg 573]</ref> According to the Shia [[Muhammad al-Baqir|fifth Imam]], however, this kind of revelation is not the revelation of prophethood but rather like the inspiration (ilham) which came to [[Mary (mother of Jesus)]],{{efn|[http://tanzil.net/#3:45 Quran, 3:45]}} the mother of Moses{{efn|[http://tanzil.net/#28:7 Quran, 28:7]}} and to the bee.{{efn|[http://tanzil.net/#16:68 Quran, 16:68]}}<ref>{{harvnb|Momen|1985|p=149}}</ref>
==Khums== According to Twelver religious practice, [[Khums]] is an annual taxation on 20% of all profits. This wealth is collected and managed by Shia religious leaders. However, according to scholars such as [[Musa al-Musawi]], the modern development of the practice of collecting khums exclusively by Shia religious leaders, especially the [[sayyid]] clerical elite, is simply a case of the usurpation of the place of the hidden Imam Mahdi and as a way of enriching the clerical class.<ref>al-Shra wa-l-taskih, [[Musa al-Musawi]], pp. 65-76</ref><ref>The Just Ruler in Shi'ite Islam, [[Abdulaziz Sachedina]], pp. 237-45</ref><ref>Shi'a Islam: From Religion to Revolution, [[Heinz Halm]], pp. 93-94</ref>
Khums, according to Shiite, is divided into two portions. One portion went to the descendants of Muhammad, the other portion was divided equally and one part given to Imam and clergy, while the other part went to the orphaned and poor Muslims.<ref>John L. Esposito (2004), The Oxford Dictionary of Islam, Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|978-0195125597}}, pp. 174</ref> Khums became a major source of income and financial independence of the clergy in Shia regions.<ref>{{harvnb|Momen|1985|p=179}}</ref>
Shias justify the practice of khums by the fact that unlike Sunni religious leaders, non-Iranian Shia ones, aren't state sponsored and supported in their mission. For example, Turkish "[[Presidency of Religious Affairs]]" only trains and employs all of Turkey’s Sunni imams, as well as administers only Sunni worshiping places, despite the fact that [[Islam in Turkey|Shias make up 25-30% of Turkish citizens]] and on non-voluntary basis participate in the financing of the Sunni mosques and the salaries of Sunni imams, while their places of worship, which are not officially recognized by the State, don't receive any funding.
==Three prayer times per day== While Sunnis have 5 [[salat]] (prayer) sessions per day, Twelvers can opt to pray only 3 times per day by doubling their prayers on 2 occasions<ref>''2017? How to Survive: Road-Testing the Options, Looking for Loopholes'', by Kevin Staffa, p. 66.</ref><ref>''Islamic Customs and Culture'', by Jason Porterfield, p. 10.</ref><ref>''Textbook on Muslim Law'', by Rakesh Kumar Singh, p. 26.</ref>—combining the 2nd prayer with the 3rd and the 4th prayer with the 5th.<ref>''Muslim Cultures Today: A Reference Guide'', edited by Kathryn M. Coughlin, p. 91.</ref><ref>''Islam: A Concise Introduction'', by Neal Robinson, p. 98.</ref> However, Sunnis argue this very practice defeats the purpose of having 5 distinct prayers, since God ordered 5 prayers for 5 separate times of the day rather than 3 prayers for 3 separate times of the day and that Shia have misrepresented the ambiguity of the issue in the Quran for their own convenience.<ref>''Muslims: Bio-cultural Perspective'', by S. H. M. Rizvi, Shibani Roy, p. 5.</ref><ref>''World Criminal Justice Systems: A Comparative Survey'', by Richard J. Terrill, p. 605.</ref> Twelvers extract this ruling from the two most important sources of jurisprudence which are the Quran<ref>{{Cite quran|17|78|style=ref}}</ref> and the Sunnah of the Messenger Muhammad who was praying this way, as it is also reported by Sunni sources,<ref>{{hadith-usc|usc=yes|Muslim|4|1515}}</ref><ref>{{hadith-usc|usc=yes|Muslim|4|1516}}</ref><ref>{{hadith-usc|usc=yes|Muslim|4|1520}}</ref><ref>{{hadith-usc|usc=yes|Muslim|4|1522}}</ref><ref>{{hadith-usc|usc=yes|Muslim|4|1523}}</ref><ref>{{hadith-usc|usc=yes|Muslim|4|1524}}</ref> thus they believe this backs their claims accepted within a Sunni point of view. It is even reported from the hadith that the Messenger did this so that ''no one among his Ummah should be put to [unnecessary] hardship'' however this can also be interpreted for people in long journey or ill health, Shias believe this is enough to reject any accusation of not basing their actions from Quran and Traditions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.al-islam.org/shiite-encyclopedia-ahlul-bayt-dilp-team/joining-prayers-and-other-related-issues|title=Joining Prayers and Other related Issues|work=Al-Islam.org}}</ref> However many Hadiths exist which support the practice of 5 prayers per day.
==Rejection of predestination== Twelvers reject [[Predestination in Islam|predestination]].<ref>''Need of Religion'', by Sayyid [[Sa'id Akhtar Rizvi]], p. 14.</ref><ref>''Islamic Beliefs, Practices, and Cultures'', by Marshall Cavendish Corporation, p. 137.</ref><ref>''Religions of Man'', by Charles Douglas Greer, p. 239.</ref><ref>''Muslims'', by S. H. M. Rizvi, Shibani Roy, B. B. Dutta, p. 20.</ref> This has led to Sunni criticism of Twelvers, along with their associated belief in [[Bada']] (change in God's will), as being deniers of God's complete [[sovereignty]] and as being imitators of the [[Mu'tazila]] school of Islamic theology.<ref>''Ethnic Composition and Crisis in South Asia: Pakistan'', by Haraprasad Chattopadhyaya, Sanat K. Sarkar, pp. 766-7.</ref><ref>''The Sunni-Shia Conflict in Pakistan'', by Mūsá Ḵẖān Jalālzaʼī, pp. 279-80.</ref>
To show that there is no contradiction between being predestined, and free will, Shiite states that matters relating to the human destiny is of two kinds: definite and indefinite; to explain the definitive one, Shiite argues that God has definite power over the whole of existence, however, whenever He wills, He can replace a given destiny with another one; and that is what is called indefinite destiny. some of these changes of destiny, thus, are brought about by man himself, who can through his free will, his decisions, and his way of life—lay the groundwork for a change in his destiny as been pointed out in the verses: ''Truly, God will not change the condition of a people as long as they do not change Their state themselves.''{{efn|[http://tanzil.net/#13:11 Quran, 13:11]}} Both types of destinies, however, are contained within God's foreknowledge, Shiite argues, so that there could be no sort of change (Bada)concerning His knowledge. So the first type of destiny does not mean a limitation of God’s power; since God, in contrast to the belief of Jews who says ''the hand of God is tied’'' asserts: ''Nay, His hands are spread out wide ...''.{{efn|[http://tanzil.net/#5:64 Quran, 5:64]}} So God has the power to change everything he wills and God's creativity is continuous. Accordingly, as Sobhani puts it, "all groups in Islam regard "bada" as a tenet of the faith, even if not all actually use the term."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Sobhani|first1=Ja'far|title=Doctrines of Shi'i Islam|publisher=I.B.Tauris in association with The Institute of Ismaili Studies|others=Translated and Edited by Reza Shah-Kazemi|location=London - New York|pages=159–163}}</ref>
==Corruption of the Quran== {{main|Shia view of the Quran}} Twelvers are often criticised by Sunnis for believing that the Quran was altered by the Sahaba (companions of Muhammad). Groups such as the [[Deobandis]] accuse Twelvers of believing that the complete version of the original Quran is in the possession of their 12th Imam. Twelvers are also accused of believing that the present Quran is omitted of the verses which support the Imamate of Ali because Caliph Uthman removed them during the Qurans compilation—noting the incompatibility of the belief that the codification and propagation of the Quran was truthfully undertaken by the Sahaba, who, in Shi'a tradition, represent the earliest people to take the Caliphate from its rightful claimants and to have corrupted the religion of Islam. As a result, such Sunni groups reject the Shia defense that they believe in the same Quran as Sunnis, accusing Shiites of lying in line with their practice of taqiyya so as not to expose themselves to the certain Sunni backlash.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Muhammad Moj|title=The Deoband Madrassah Movement: Countercultural Trends and Tendencies|date=1 Mar 2015|publisher=Anthem Press|location=Appendix I: The Deobandi Stance vis-a-vis Muslim Groups Other Than The Barelwis: B. The DMM on Shia Muslims: iii. Changes in the Quran|isbn=9781783084463}}<!--|accessdate=28 April 2015--></ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Aaron Hughes|title=Muslim Identities: An Introduction to Islam|date=23 Apr 2013|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=9780231161473|page=131|edition=illustrated}}<!--|accessdate=28 April 2015--></ref>
Most of Shiites nowadays believe that nothing have been omitted or added to the [[Quran]], however, traces of earlier views can be find in some Hadith books like [[Bihar al-Anwar]].<ref>{{harvnb|Momen|1985|p=172}}</ref> The contemporary Shiite scholar [[Abu al-Qasim al-Khoei]] states that even if The Book of Ali (a copy of [[Quran]] written by [[Ali]] containing Ali's commentary, which sometimes is called the Book of Ali)<ref name= "Moojan">{{harvnb|Momen|1985|p=150}}</ref> incorporated additions that are not part of the existing Quran, this does not mean that these additions comprised parts of the Quran and have been dropped from it due to alteration. Rather, these additions were interpretations or explanations of what God was saying, or were in the form of revelations from God, explaining the intention of the verses in the Quran. These additions were not part of the Quran and not part of what the [[Muhammad|Messenger of God]] was commanded to convey to the Muslim community.<ref>{{cite book|last=Al-Khu'i|first=Al-Sayyid|title=The Prolegomena to the Qur'an|year=1998|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=New York|isbn=0-19-511675-5|pages=154–155}}</ref>
==Karbala== [[Image:Kerbela Hussein Moschee.jpg|thumb|right|Shia pilgrims gather around the shrine of Husayn in Karbala.]] Twelvers have been accused of raising [[Karbala]] to holiness and prominence—which in itself is "frowned upon by Sunnis"—above even [[Makka]], [[Medina]] and [[Jerusalem]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Barry Rubin|title=The Middle East: A Guide to Politics, Economics, Society and Culture|date=17 Mar 2015|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317455783|page=329}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Ingvar Svanberg|author2=David Westerlund|editor1-last=Svanberg|editor1-first=Ingvar|editor2-last=Westerlund|editor2-first=David|title=Islam Outside the Arab World|date=6 Dec 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136113222|page=9}}</ref> This belief is exemplified by the attribution of the title ''Karbala-i'' for one who has performed pilgrimage there (just as one who makes the [[Hajj]] is titled [[Hajji]]), its annual attraction of more pilgrims for [[Day of Ashura|Ashura]] and [[Arba'een]] than the Hajj (seen as "a counterweight and a challenge to the annual haj taking place in Mecca"), prostrating during [[salat]] on [[turbah]] commonly made from the clay of Karbala and to numerous [[hadith]] attributed to the Imams which are interpreted by critics as placing the land of Karbala above the [[Kaaba]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Gilles Kepel|title=The War for Muslim Minds: Islam and the West|date=2004|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=9780674015753|page=225|edition=illustrated}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Mahmoud M. Ayoub|authorlink=Mahmoud M. Ayoub |title=Redemptive Suffering in Islam: A Study of the Devotional Aspects of Ashura in Twelver Shi'ism|date=1 Jan 1978|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|isbn=9783110803310|pages=181–3|edition=reprint}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Wayne Rollen Husted|title=Shahīd-i S̲ālis̲ Qāz̤ī Nārullāh Shūstarī: An Historical Figure in Shīite Piety|date=1992|publisher=University of Wisconsin--Madison|pages=158–9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=El-Sayed el-Aswad|title=Muslim Worldviews and Everyday Lives|date=13 Jul 2012|publisher=Rowman Altamira|isbn=9780759121218|page=65|edition=illustrated}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=de Jong|editor1-first=F.|title=Shīʻa Islam, Sects, and Sufism: Historical Dimensions, Religious Practice and Methodological Considerations|date=1992|publisher=M.Th. Houtsma Stichting|isbn=9789080104013|page=134}}</ref> Sunni criticism has recently extended to a proposal by former Prime Minister of Iraq [[Nouri al-Maliki]] to even make Karbala the [[Qibla]] (direction of prayer).<ref>{{cite news|author1=Ari Yashar|title=Iraq Changes Prayer Direction: Karbala, Not Mecca|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/175607#.Vi9HUNIrJR1|accessdate=27 October 2015|work=Arutz Sheva|date=27 December 2013}}</ref>
==Violence and persecution== Iran, the Twelver Shia bastion, is accused of the persecution of its [[Religion in Iran#Sunni Islam|Sunni minority]] and the historical persecution of Sunnis since at least [[Safavid]] times,<ref>{{cite news|author1=DAVID A. GRAHAM|title=Iran’s Beleaguered Sunnis|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2016/01/iran-sunnis-saudi/422877/|accessdate=4 February 2016|work=[[The Atlantic]]|date=6 Jan 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Iran: RELIGIOUS MINORITIES: Sunni Muslims|url=https://www.hrw.org/reports/1997/iran/Iran-05.htm|website=[[Human Rights Watch]]|accessdate=4 February 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1=Raihan Ismail|title=Saudi Clerics and Shi'a Islam|date=2016|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780190233327|page=153}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Global Issues: Selections from CQ Researcher|date=2013|publisher=CQ Press|isbn=9781483300887|page=34}}</ref> e.g. there are no Sunni mosques in any of Iran’s large cities.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Ershad Alijani|title=Tehran's authorities destroy Sunni worship space|url=http://observers.france24.com/en/20150806-iran-islam-mosque-shia-sunni-religion|accessdate=1 May 2017|work=France 24|date=8 June 2015}}</ref> It is also accused of supporting the suppression of Sunnis in such countries as [[Sunni Islam in Lebanon|Lebanon]], [[Islam in Syria#Sunni Islam|Syria]] and [[Iraq]], both directly and through the militias it funds, such as [[Hezbollah]] and the [[private militias in Iraq]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Bernard Rougier|title=The Sunni Tragedy in the Middle East: Northern Lebanon from al-Qaeda to ISIS|date=2015|publisher=Princeton University Press|isbn=9781400873579|page=73}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Sophie McNeill|title=Saudi Arabia cutting diplomatic ties with Iran - fears of new sectarian clash|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2016-01-04/saudi-arabia-cutting-diplomatic-ties-with-iran--/7065804|accessdate=4 February 2016|work=AM|publisher=ABC|date=4 Jan 2016}}</ref> Another common target of persecution by the Iranian Twelver religious establishment [[Persecution of Bahá'ís#Iran|is the Bahá'í]] community.
However, Twelvers have themselves often been victims of [[Anti-Shi'ism|Anti-Shia]] violence.
