[[File:PikiWiki Israel 9089 Water Festival at Kibbutz Ramat Yohanan.jpg|thumb|261px|[[Water Festival]], Kibbutz [[Ramat Yohanan]]]] {{JewishMusic}}
'''Jewish dance''' refers to [[dance]] associated with [[Jews]] and [[Judaism]]. Dance has long been used by Jews as a medium for the expression of joy and other communal emotions. Dancing was a favorite pastime and played a role in religious observance.<ref>Landa, M. J. (1926). ''The Jew in Drama'', p. 17. New York: Ktav Publishing House (1969). Each [[Jewish diaspora|Jewish diasporic]] community developed its own dance traditions for wedding celebrations and other distinguished events.</ref>
Dances associated with [[Ashkenazi Jews|Ashkenazi]] and [[Sephardi Jews|Sephardi]] traditions, especially [[Jewish wedding]] dances, are an integral part of Jewish life in [[United States|America]] and around the world. Folk dances associated with [[Zionism]] and the formation of the State of [[Israel]] became popular in the 1950s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jewish-theatre.com/visitor/article_display.aspx?articleID=2680 |title=Jewish Dance in America |publisher=Jewish-theatre.com |date=2009-02-03 |accessdate=2013-02-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127110539/http://www.jewish-theatre.com/visitor/article_display.aspx?articleID=2680 |archivedate=2013-01-27 |df= }}</ref>
==Hasidic-style dance== Among [[Ashkenazi Jews]] dancing to [[klezmer]] music was an integral part of weddings in the [[shtetl]]. Jewish dance was influenced by local non-Jewish dance traditions, but there were clear differences, mainly in hand and arm motions, with more intricate legwork by the younger men.<ref>[http://borzykowska.users.ch/EnglYidDance.htm Yiddish, Klezmer, Ashkenazic or 'shtetl' dances], Le Site Genevois de la Musique Klezmer. Accessed 12 February 2006.</ref> The religious community frowned on mixed dancing, dictating separate circles for men and women.
In [[Hasidic Judaism]], dance is a tool for expressing joy and is believed to have a therapeutic effect: It purifies the soul, promotes spiritual elation and unifies the community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yivoencyclopedia.org/article.aspx/Hasidism/Dance |title=Hasidism: Dance |publisher=Yivoencyclopedia.org |date=2008-03-09 |accessdate=2013-02-15}}</ref>
===Horah===
The [[Hora (dance)|Horah]] is a Jewish circle dance typically danced to the music of ''[[Hava Nagila]]''. It is traditionally danced at [[Jewish wedding]]s and other joyous occasions in the Jewish community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldweddingtraditions.com/ethnic_wedding_traditions/jewish_traditions.html |title=Wedding traditions |publisher=Worldweddingtraditions.com |date= |accessdate=2013-02-15}}</ref> The hora was introduced in Israel by the Romanian Jewish dancer [[Baruch Agadati]]. In 1924, he worked together with a composer and songwriter to choreograph a show performed by the Ohel Theater Company, which toured the pioneer settlements of the [[Jezreel Valley]]. "Horah Agadati," as the dance was known, became an instant success.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.forward.com/articles/12226/ |title=Hora History |publisher=Forward.com |date= |accessdate=2013-02-15}}</ref>
===Yemenite step (Tza'ad Temani)=== The [[Yemenite step]] (Tza'ad Temani) is a form of dancing based on hopping in place.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imber.com.au/ifd/glossary.htm |title=Glossary of Israeli Folk Dancing |publisher=Imber.com.au |date=2009-03-19 |accessdate=2013-02-15}}</ref> Tza'ad Temani is typical of this dance form. The Tza'ad Temani is frequently incorporated in public dancing at Jewish weddings and celebrations. The [[Inbal Dance Theater]] specializes in Yemenite dancing in Israel.<ref>{{cite web|author=Dick Oakes |url=http://google.com/search?q=cache:5c5lKAZ3x8wJ:www.phantomranch.net/folkdanc/teachers/halevy_m.htm+druze+dabka+troupe+israel&cd=5&hl=en&ct=clnk |title=Inbal Dance Company |publisher=Google.com |date=2013-02-04 |accessdate=2013-02-15}}</ref>
==Ballet== In Russia and France, the [[Ballets Russes]] was "primarily a Jewish creation," according to [[Paul Johnson (writer)|Paul Johnson]].<ref>Johnson, ''op. cit.'', p. 410.<!-- Fix this reference!--></ref> In the United States, Jewish choreographers and dancers have been leading figures in the dance world, among them [[Jerome Robbins]], [[Anna Sokolow]], [[Michael Bennett (theater)|Michael Bennett]], [[Michael Kidd]], [[Ron Field]], [[Arthur Murray]], [[Helen Tamiris]] and [[Pearl Lang]]. [[Lincoln Kirstein]] was one of the founders of the [[School of American Ballet]], The American Ballet and the [[New York City Ballet]].
==Modern dance== One of the pioneers of modern dance in Israel was [[Gertrud Kraus]], who immigrated to [[Mandatory Palestine]] in 1935 and formed a modern dance company affiliated with the Tel-Aviv Folk Opera.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://jwa.org/encyclopedia/article/kraus-gertrud |title=Jewish Women's Archive: Gertrud Kraus |publisher=Jwa.org |date=2009-03-01 |accessdate=2013-02-15}}</ref> In 1950-1951, she founded the Israel Ballet Theatre, and became its artistic director.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> Contemporary dance in Israel is influenced by Israeli folk dance and European traditions. Dance companies include the Kibbutz Contemporary Dance Company, Inbal Dance Theater, [[Bat-Dor Dance Company]] and [[Batsheva Dance Company]].
==Flamenco== In 2010, Silvia Duran, an Israeli [[flamenco]] dancer, was honored by King [[Juan Carlos I of Spain]] for training generations of flamenco dancers at her studio in [[Tel Aviv]], The citation was awarded for her "contribution to the culture of Spain and the Spanish people.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/news-in-brief-1.302022 |title=Spanish monarch honors Israeli flamenco dancer with citation |publisher=Haaretz.com |date=2010-07-15 |accessdate=2013-02-15}}</ref>

{{Distinguish-otheruses|kefir|kaffir (disambiguation){{!}}kaffir}} {{Redirect|Kafr|the village in Iran|Kafr, Iran}} {{use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Islam and iman}} {{Islamism sidebar}} '''Kafir''' ({{lang-ar|كافر}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kāfir}}''; plural {{lang|ar|كَافِرُونَ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kāfirūna}}'', {{lang|ar|كفّار}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kuffār}}'' or {{lang|ar|كَفَرَة}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kafarah}}''; feminine {{lang|ar|كافرة}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kāfirah}}'') is an Arabic term (from the root K-F-R "to cover") meaning "unbeliever", or "disbeliever". The term<ref name="Bunt 2009"/> alludes to a person who rejects or disbelieves in [[God in Islam|God as described by Islam]] according to the teachings of the [[Islam]]ic prophet [[Muhammad]],<ref name=Glasse-2001-247>{{cite book|last1=Glasse|first1=Cyril|title=The New Encyclopedia of Islam|date=1989|publisher=Altamira Press|location=NY|isbn=0759101892|page=247|edition=Revised 2001}}</ref><ref>[https://www.secularismandnonreligion.org/articles/10.5334/snr.111/ Nonbelief: An Islamic Perspective]</ref> and denies the dominion and authority of the Islamic god, and is thus often translated as "[[infidel]]".<ref name=TIK/> [[Muhammad Asad]] held "infidels" to be an erroneous translation of "''kafir''" made by several scholars<ref>Ahmed Affi, Hassan Affi ''Contemporary Interpretation of Islamic Law'' Troubador Publishing Ltd 2014 {{ISBN|978-1-783-06759-6}} page 12</ref> and western Quran translations, since it is not synonymous with "non-Muslim"; thus, someone who does good deeds without any expectation of worldly rewards is not a ''kafir''.<ref>J. I. Laliwala ''Islamic Philosophy of Religion: Synthesis of Science Religion and Philosophy'' Sarup & Sons 2005 {{ISBN|978-8-176-25476-2}} page 86</ref><ref>Asghar Ali Engineer ''Islam in Contemporary World'' Sterling Publishers Pvt. Ltd 2007 {{ISBN|978-1-932-70569-0}} xvi</ref><ref>Ejaz Naqvi ''The Quran: With Or Against the Bible? : a Topic-by-topic Review for the Investigative Mind'' iUniverse 2012 {{ISBN|978-1-475-90774-2}} page 254</ref> At the same time, ''kafir'' is sometimes used as a derogatory term,<ref>{{cite book|last=Rajan|first=Julie|title=Al Qaeda’s Global Crisis: The Islamic State, Takfir and the Genocide of Muslims| page =cii|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pz5yBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA102&dq=kuffar+derogatory&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCAQ6AEwAGoVChMIns6cnPrIxwIVqSPbCh2tfAMO#v=onepage&q=kuffar%20derogatory&f=false|date=30 January 2015|publisher=Routledge|accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref><ref name="Bunt 2009">{{cite book|last=Bunt|first=Gary|title=Muslims| page =ccxxiv|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gpz2v-6cnsEC&pg=PA224&dq=kuffar+derogatory&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCYQ6AEwAWoVChMIns6cnPrIxwIVqSPbCh2tfAMO#v=onepage&q=kuffar%20derogatory&f=false|date=2009|publisher=The Other Press|accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Pruniere|first=Gerard|title=Darfur: The Ambiguous Genocide| page =xvi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MctyAAAAMAAJ&q=kuffar+derogatory&dq=kuffar+derogatory&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCsQ6AEwAmoVChMIns6cnPrIxwIVqSPbCh2tfAMO|date=1 January 2007|publisher=Cornell University Press|accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref> particularly by members of [[Islamism|Islamist]] movements.<ref>Emmanuel M. Ekwo ''Racism and Terrorism: Aftermath of 9/11'' Author House 2010 {{ISBN|978-1-452-04748-5}} page 143</ref> Unbelief is called ''kufr''. ''Kafir'' is sometimes used interchangeably with ''[[shirk (Islam)|mushrik]]'' ({{lang|ar|مشرك}}, those who commit polytheism), another type of religious wrongdoer mentioned frequently in the Quran and other Islamic works.<ref name=IQA>{{cite web|author1=Shaykh Muhammad Saalih al-Munajjid|title=Islam Question and Answer|url=http://islamqa.info/en/67626|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> The practice of declaring another self-professed Muslim a ''kafir'' is known as ''[[takfir]]''.<ref name="oxforddictionaries.com">{{cite web |title=kafir |website=[[OxfordDictionaries.com]] |url=http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/kafir |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512211202/http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/kafir |archive-date=2015-05-12}}</ref> The person who [[Atheism|denies the existence of a creator]] is called ''Dahriya''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Swartz|first=Merlin|title=A medieval critique of Anthropomorphism| page =96|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_5dbo6vYOREC&pg=PA96&lpg=PA96&dq=dahriya&source=bl&ots=RCx7M3ucba&sig=K8HmJn7RnRTZzVP6W70PzlJ6sbU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjpkrS4yqfVAhXBerwKHdiRD_AQ6AEIPzAM#v=onepage&q=dahriya&f=false|date=30 January 2015|publisher=Brill|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref>
==Etymology== The word ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kāfir}}'' is the active participle of the [[triliteral|root]] [[K-P-R|K-F-R]]. As a pre-Islamic term it described farmers burying seeds in the ground. One of its applications in the Quran is also the same meaning as farmer.<ref>(أَعْجَبَ الْكُفَّارَ نَبَاتُهُ) [https://archive.is/20120723132603/http://www.bookstree.com/books/2/k4/k_p4_p314.htm Surah 57 Al-Hadid (Iron) Ayah 20]</ref> Since farmers cover the seeds with soil while planting, the word ''{{transl|ar|DIN|kāfir}}'' implies a person who hides or covers. Ideologically, it implies a person who hides or covers the truth. Poets personify the darkness of night as kâfir, perhaps as a survival of pre-Islamic religious or mythological usage.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Goldziher|first1=Ignác|title=Mythology among the Hebrews|date=1877|accessdate=2015-06-28|page=193|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/48967/48967-h/48967-h.htm#Page_193}}</ref> The noun for disbelief,<ref>{{cite web|title=Islamic terminology|url=http://islamic-dictionary.tumblr.com/post/10098203002/kufr-arabic-is-the-term-which-describes|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> "blasphemy",<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mansour|first1=Ahmed|title=Ahl al-Quran|url=http://www.ahl-alquran.com/English/show_article.php?main_id=6306|accessdate=11 June 2015|date=24 September 2006}}</ref> "impiety"<ref>{{cite book|last1=Kepel|first1=Gilles|title=Jihad: The Trail of Political Islam|date=2002|publisher=Harvard University Press|page=31|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OLvTNk75hUoC&pg=PA31&lpg=PA31&dq=definition+kufr+impiety&source=bl&ots=vBDz07KPT4&sig=nJM9v0ra0YtI-_mZ90y1c3lVxEY&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDgQ6AEwBGoVChMIxbL6ma2GxgIVIiSMCh2PFArk#v=onepage&q=definition%20kufr%20impiety&f=false|accessdate=11 June 2015}}</ref> rather than the person who disbelieves, is ''kufr''.
The [[Hebrew]] words "''kipper''" and "''kofer''" share the same root as "''kafir''" כִּפֵּר, or [[K-F-R]]. "Kipper" has many meanings including, to "deny", "atone for", "cover", "purge", "represent", or "transfer". The last two meanings involve "[[kofer]]" that mean "ransom". "Kipper" and "kofer" are mostly likely used together in the [[Judaism|Jewish]] faith to indicate God's [[Scapegoat#The Bible|transfer of guilt from innocent parties using guilty parties]] as "ransom".<ref>{{cite book |url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/article-1G2-2587511157/kipper.html |title="Kipper" Encyclopaedia Judaica|year=2007|publisher=Macmillan Reference USA|location=Detroit|pages=180–83|edition=2nd|editor=Michael Berenbaum and Fred Skolnik |accessdate=26 September 2013}}</ref>
==Usage== The practice of declaring another Muslim as a ''kafir'' is ''[[takfir]]''.<ref name="oxforddictionaries.com"/> ''Kufr'' (unbelief) and ''shirk'' (polytheism) are used throughout the Quran and sometimes used interchangeably by Muslims.<ref name=IQA/><ref name=QSEP>{{cite web|last1=Ibn Baaz|title=What is the Difference between Kufr and Shirk? [Fatawa Ibn Baaz]|url=http://qsep.com/modules.php?name=ilm&d_op=article&sid=888|website=Quran Sunnah Educational Programs|accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref> According to Salafist scholars, ''Kufr'' is the "denial of the Truth" (truth in the form of articles of faith in Islam), and ''shirk'' means devoting "acts of worship to anything beside God"<ref name=QSEP/> or "the worship of idols and other created beings".<ref name=IQA/> So a mushrik may worship other things while also "acknowledging God".<ref name=IQA/>
==In the Quran==
The distinction between those who believe in Islam and those who do not is an essential one in the Quran, the book of Islam. ''Kafir'', and its plural ''kuffaar'', is used directly 134 times in Quran, its verbal noun "''kufr''" is used 37 times, and the verbal cognates of ''kafir'' are used about 250 times.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Campo |first1= Juan Eduardo |year=2009 |title=Encyclopedia of Islam |publisher=Infobase Publishing| ISBN=9781438126968| pages=420–22|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OZbyz_Hr-eIC&pg=PA420&dq=encyclopedia+of+islam+kafir&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB4Q6AEwAGoVChMI6sPd96-IxgIVj3ySCh031QCU#v=onepage&q=encyclopedia%20of%20islam%20kafir&f=false}}</ref>
By extension of the basic meaning of the root, "to cover", the term is used in the Quran in the senses of ignore/fail to acknowledge and to spurn/be ungrateful.<ref name=EoQ-Belief>{{Cite encyclopedia|author=Adang, Camilla | year= 2006 | title=Belief and Unbelief|encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of the Qurʾān|editor=Jane Dammen McAuliffe|url=http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopaedia-of-the-quran/belief-and-unbelief-EQCOM_00025|publisher=Brill|subscription=yes}}</ref> The meaning of "disbelief", which has come to be regarded as primary, retains all of these connotations in the Quranic usage.<ref name=EoQ-Belief/> In the Quranic discourse, the term typifies all things that are unacceptable and offensive to the Islamic God.<ref name=adams>{{cite encyclopedia|author=Charles Adams (rev. by A. Kevin Reinhart)|title=Kufr|encyclopedia=The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World|editor=John L. Esposito|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|year=2009|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780195305135.001.0001/acref-9780195305135-e-0467|subscription=yes}}</ref> Charles Adams writes that the most fundamental sense of ''kufr'' in the Quran is "ingratitude", the willful refusal to acknowledge or appreciate the benefits that the Islamic God bestows on humankind, including clear signs and revealed scriptures.<ref name=adams/>
According to the ''E. J. Brill's First Encyclopaedia of Islam, 1913–1936, Volume 4'', the term first applied in the Quran to unbelieving Meccans, who endeavoured "to refute and revile the Prophet". A waiting attitude towards the ''kafir'' was recommended at first for Muslims; later, Muslims were ordered to keep apart from unbelievers and defend themselves against their attacks and even take the offensive.<ref name=EJBFEI-619/> Most passages in the Quran referring to unbelievers in general talk about their fate on the [[Islamic eschatology|day of judgement]] and destination in [[Jahannam|hell]].<ref name=EJBFEI-619/>
According to scholar Marilyn Waldman, as the Quran "progresses" (as the reader goes from the verses revealed first to later ones), the meaning behind the term ''kafir'' does not change but "progresses", i.e. "accumulates meaning over time". As the [[Prophet Muhammad|Islamic Prophet Muhammad]]'s views of his opponents change, his use of ''kafir'' "undergoes a development". ''Kafir'' moves from being ''one'' description of Muhammad's opponents to the primary one. Later in the Quran, ''kafir'' becomes more and more connected with ''[[Shirk (Islam)|shirk]]''. Finally, towards the end of the [[Quran]], ''kafir'' begins to also signify the group of people to be fought by the ''mu'minīn'' (believers).<ref>{{cite journal|last=Waldman|first=Marilyn|title=The Development of the Concept of Kufr in the Qur'an|journal=Journal of the American Oriental Society|date=Jul–Sep 1968|volume=88|issue=3|pages=442–55|doi=10.2307/596869|jstor=596869}}</ref>
==Types of unbelievers==
===People of the Book=== The status of the [[People of the Book]] (''ahl al-kitab''), particularly Jews and Christians, with respect to the Islamic notions of unbelief is not clearcut. Charles Adams writes that the Quran reproaches the People of the Book with ''kufr'' for rejecting Muhammad's message when they should have been the first to accept it as possessors of earlier revelations, and singles out Christians for disregarding the evidence of God's unity.<ref name=adams/> The Quranic verse 5:73 ("Certainly they disbelieve [''kafara''] who say: God is the third of three"), among other verses, has been traditionally understood in Islam as [[Islamic view of the Trinity|rejection of the Christian Trinity doctrine]],<ref name=EoQ-Trinity>{{Cite encyclopedia|author=Thomas, David | year= 2006 | title=Trinity|encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of the Qurʾān|editor=Jane Dammen McAuliffe|url=http://referenceworks.brillonline.com/entries/encyclopaedia-of-the-quran/trinity-EQSIM_00428|publisher=Brill|subscription=yes}}</ref> though modern scholarship has suggested alternative interpretations.{{refn|group=note|That this verse criticizes a deviant form of Trinitarian belief which overstressed distinctiveness of the three persons at the expense of their unity. Modern scholars have also interpreted it as a reference to Jesus, who was often called "the third of three" in Syriac literature and as an intentional over-simplification of Christian doctrine intended to highlight its weakness from a strictly monotheistic perspective.<ref name=EoQ-Trinity/>}} Other Quranic verses strongly deny the [[Hypostatic union|deity of Jesus Christ]], son of Mary and reproach the people who treat Jesus as equal with God as disbelievers who will be doomed to eternal punishment in [[Hell]].<ref>Joseph, Jojo, ''[http://theolibrary.shc.edu/resources/Quran-Gospel.pdf Qur’an-Gospel Convergence: The Qur’an’s Message To Christians]'', ''Journal of Dharma'', 1 (January–March 2010), pp. 55-76</ref><ref>Mazuz, Haggai (2012) [https://journal.fi/store/article/download/9525/6759 ''Christians in the Qurʾān: Some Insights Derived from the Classical Exegetic Approach''], Journal of Dharma 35, 1 (January–March 2010), 55-76</ref> While the Quran does not recognize the attribute of Jesus as the Son of God or God himself, it respects Jesus as a prophet and messenger of God sent to children of Israel.<ref>Schirrmacher, Christine, ''The Islamic view of Christians: Qur’an and Hadith'', http://www.worldevangelicals.org</ref> Some Muslim thinkers such as [[Mohamed Talbi]] have viewed the most extreme Quranic presentations of the dogmas of the Trinity and divinity of Jesus (5:19, 5:75-76, 5:119) as non-Christian formulas that were rejected by the Church.<ref>{{cite book|author=Carré, Olivier|year=2003|title=Mysticism and Politics: A Critical Reading of Fī Ẓilāl Al-Qurʼān by Sayyid Quṭb|location=Boston|publisher=Brill|pages=63–64|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N85UaTV-0VoC&pg=PA63}}</ref>
Cyril Glasse criticizes the use of ''kafirun'' [pl. of ''kafir''] to describe Christians as "loose usage".<ref name=Glasse-2001-247/> According to the ''[[Encyclopedia of Islam]]'', in traditional [[Fiqh|Islamic jurisprudence]], ''ahl al-kitab'' are "usually regarded more leniently than other ''kuffar'' [pl. of ''kafir'']..." and "in theory" a Muslim commits a punishable offense if he says to a Jew or a Christian: "Thou unbeliever".<ref name=EI2>{{Cite encyclopedia|author=Björkman, W. | year= 2012 | title=Kāfir |encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Islam| edition=2nd|publisher=Brill |editors=P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel, W.P. Heinrichs|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/1573-3912_islam_SIM_3775|subscription=yes}}</ref>
Historically, People of the Book permanently residing under Islamic rule were entitled to a special status known as ''[[dhimmi]]'', while those visiting Muslim lands received a different status known as ''[[musta'min]]''.<ref name=EI2/>
===''Mushrikun''===
''Mushrikun'' (pl. of ''mushrik'') are those who practice ''[[Shirk (Islam)|shirk]]'', which literally means "association" and refers to accepting other gods and divinities alongside the god of the Muslims - Allah (as God's "associates").<ref name=EI2-shirk>{{Cite encyclopedia|author=Gimaret, D. | year= 2012 | title=S̲h̲irk |encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Islam| edition=2nd|publisher=Brill |editors=P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel, W.P. Heinrichs|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1163/1573-3912_islam_SIM_6965|subscription=yes}}</ref> The term is often translated as polytheism.<ref name=EI2-shirk/> The Quran distinguishes between ''mushrikun'' and People of the Book, reserving the former term for idol worshipers, although some classical commentators considered Christian doctrine to be a form of ''shirk''.<ref name=EI2-shirk/> ''Shirk'' is held to be the worst form of disbelief, and it is identified in the Quran as the only sin that God cannot pardon (4:48, 4:116).<ref name=EI2-shirk/>
Accusations of ''shirk'' have been common in religious polemics within Islam.<ref name=EI2-shirk/> Thus, in the early Islamic debates on free will and [[theodicy]], Sunni theologians charged their [[Mu'tazila]] adversaries with ''shirk'', accusing them of attributing to man creative powers comparable to those of God in both originating and executing his own actions.<ref name=EI2-shirk/> Mu'tazila theologians, in turn, charged the Sunnis with ''shirk'' on the grounds that under their doctrine a voluntary human act would result from an "association" between God, who creates the act, and the individual who appropriates it by carrying it out.<ref name=EI2-shirk/>
In classical jurisprudence, Islamic religious tolerance applied only to the People of the Book, while ''mushrikun'', based on the [[Sword Verse]], faced a choice between conversion to Islam and fight to the death,<ref name=hallaq>{{cite book|author=Wael B. Hallaq|authorlink = Wael Hallaq|title=Sharī'a: Theory, Practice, Transformations|year=2009|publisher=Cambridge University Press (Kindle edition)|page=327 }}</ref> which may be substituted by enslavement.<ref name=lewis-1995-230>{{cite book|last1=Lewis|first1=Bernard|title=The Middle East, A Brief History of the Last 2000 Years|date=1995|publisher=Touchstone|isbn=0684832801|page=230}}</ref> In practice, the designation of People of the Book and the ''dhimmi'' status was extended even to non-monotheistic religions of conquered peoples, such as Hinduism.<ref name=hallaq/> Following destruction of major Hindu temples during the [[Muslim conquests of the Indian subcontinent|Muslim conquests in South Asia]], Hindus and Muslims on the subcontinent came to share a number of popular religious practices and beliefs, such as veneration of [[Wali|Sufi saints]] and worship at Hindu shrines.<ref>{{Cite book| last = Lapidus | first = Ira M. | authorlink=Ira M. Lapidus | title = A History of Islamic Societies | publisher = Cambridge University Press (Kindle edition) | year = 2014| isbn=978-0-521-51430-9 | pages= 391, 396}}</ref>
===Sinners=== Whether a Muslim could commit a sin great enough to become a ''kafir'' was disputed by jurists in the early centuries of Islam. The most tolerant view (that of the ''Murdji'a'') was that even those who had committed a major sin (''kabira'') were still believers and "their fate was left to God".<ref name=EJBFEI-619/> The most strict view (that of Kharidji Ibadis, descended from the [[Kharijites]]) was that every Muslim who dies having not repented of his sins was considered a ''kafir''. In between these two positions, the ''Mu'tazila'' believed that there was a status between believer and unbeliever called "rejected" or ''[[fasiq]]''.<ref name=EJBFEI-619/>
===''Takfir''=== The [[Kharijites]] view that the self-proclaimed Muslim who had sinned and "failed to repent had ipso facto excluded himself from the community, and was hence a kafir" (a practice known as ''takfir'') was considered so extreme by the [[Sunni Islam|Sunni]] majority that they in turn declared the [[Kharijites]] ''kafir'',<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ruthven|first=Malise|title=The Eleventh of September and the Sudanese mahdiya in the Context of Ibn Khaldun's Theory of Islamic History|journal=International Affairs|date=April 2002|volume=78|issue=2|pages=344–45|doi=10.1111/1468-2346.00254}}<!--|accessdate=2 December 2012--></ref> following the hadith that declared, "If a Muslim charges a fellow Muslim with ''kufr'', he is himself a ''kafir'' if the accusation should prove untrue".<ref name=EJBFEI-619/>
Nevertheless, in Islamic theological polemics ''kafir'' was "a frequent term for the Muslim protagonist" holding the opposite view, according to ''Brill's Islamic Encyclopedia''.<ref name=EJBFEI-619>{{cite book|editor1-last=Houtsma|editor1-first=M. Th.|title=E. J. Brill's First Encyclopaedia of Islam, 1913–1936, Volume 4|publisher=Brill|page=619|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7CP7fYghBFQC&pg=PA619&lpg=PA619&dq=kafir+ahl+al-kitab&source=bl&ots=F7FtqhNJb8&sig=cnybHFVfgxct43lb7o-zpoEAfdM&hl=en&sa=X&ei=jqeRVa7EL8WrogT4-KygCg&ved=0CFAQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=kafir%20ahl%20al-kitab&f=false|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref>
===''Murtad''=== Another group that are "distinguished from the mass of kafirun"<ref name=EJBFEI-619/> are the ''[[Apostasy in Islam|murtad]]'', or apostate ex-Muslims, who are considered renegades and traitors, the concept of [[freedom of religion]] not being accepted.<ref name=EJBFEI-619/> Their traditional punishment is death, even, according to some scholars, if they recant their abandonment of Islam.<ref name=lewis-1995-230q>{{cite book|last1=Lewis|first1=Bernard|title=The Middle East, A Brief History of the Last 2000 Years|date=1995|publisher=Touchstone|isbn=0684832801|page=230|quote=Tolerance may in no circumstances be extended to the apostate, the renegade Muslim, whose punishment is death. Some authorities allow the remission of this punishment if the apostate recants. Others insist on the death penalty even then. God may pardon him the world to come; the law must punish him in this world.}}</ref>
=== ''Mu'ahid'' / ''dhimmi'' === Non-Muslims living under the protection of an [[Islamic state]].<ref>“muʿāhad”, in: ''Encyclopaedia of Islam, Second Edition, Glossary and Index of Terms'', Edited by: P.J. Bearman, Th. Banquis, C.E. Bowworth, E. van Donzel, W. P. Heinrichs Bowworth. Consulted online on 06 August 2018 <http://dx.doi.org/10.1163/1573-3912_ei2glos_SIM_gi_03145>
First published online: 2012
First print edition: {{ISBN|97890041444484}}, PAGES 137-592, 20090501</ref><ref>“Muʿāhid”, in: ''Encyclopaedia of Islam, Second Edition'', Edited by: P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel, W.P. Heinrichs. Consulted online on 06 August 2018 <http://dx.doi.org/10.1163/1573-3912_islam_DUM_3909>
First published online: 2012
First print edition: {{ISBN|9789004161214}}, 1960-2007</ref>
==Types of disbelief== Muslim belief/doctrine is often summarized in "[[Iman (concept)#The Six Articles of Faith|the Six Articles of Faith]]",<ref name=RF>{{cite web|title=Six Articles of the Islamic Faith|url=http://www.religionfacts.com/islam/practices/six-articles|website=Religion Facts|accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> (the first five are mentioned together in the Qur'an 2:285<ref>{{quran-usc|2|285|s=ns}}</ref>).
# [[God in Islam|God]]<ref name=q-trans/> # His [[Islamic view of angels|angels]]<ref name=q-trans/> # His [[Prophets and messengers in Islam|Messengers]]<ref name=q-trans/> # His [[Islamic holy books|Revealed Books]],<ref name=q-trans/> # The [[Islamic eschatology|Day of Resurrection]]<ref name=q-trans/> # ''[[Predestination in Islam|Al-Qadar]]'', Divine Preordainments, i.e. whatever God has ordained must come to pass<ref name=q-trans/>
According to the [[Salafi]] scholar [[Muhammad Taqi-ud-Din al-Hilali]], "''kufr'' is basically disbelief in any of the articles of faith. He also lists several different types of major disbelief, (disbelief so severe it excludes those who practice it completely from the fold of Islam):
# ''Kufr-at-Takdhib'': disbelief in divine truth or the denial of any of the articles of Faith (quran 39:32)<ref name=q-trans/> # ''Kufr-al-iba wat-takabbur ma'at-Tasdiq'': refusing to submit to God's Commandments after conviction of their truth (quran 2:34)<ref name=q-trans/> # ''Kufr-ash-Shakk waz-Zann'': doubting or lacking conviction in the six articles of Faith. (quran 18:35–38)<ref name=q-trans/> # ''Kufr-al-I'raadh'': turning away from the truth knowingly or deviating from the obvious signs which God has revealed. (quran 46:3)<ref name=q-trans/> # ''[[Munafiq|Kufr-an-Nifaaq]]'': hypocritical disbelief (quran 63:2–3)<ref name=q-trans>{{cite book|last1=Taqi-ud-Din Al-Hilali|first1=Muhammad|first2=Muhammad Muhsin|last2=Khan|title=The Holy Quran Translation|publisher=ideas4islam|pages=901–02|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dMK6fNcjg44C&pg=PA901&dq=Al-Kufr+al-Akbar&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCkQ6AEwAmoVChMI1fjUj8iUxgIViCqICh38WAA5#v=onepage&q=Al-Kufr%20al-Akbar&f=false|accessdate=16 June 2015}}</ref>
Minor disbelief or ''Kufran-Ni'mah '' indicates "ungratefulness of God's Blessings or Favours".<ref name=q-trans/>
According to another source, a paraphrase of the [[Tafsir]] by [[Ibn Kathir]],<ref name=TIK>{{cite web|url = http://www.sunnahonline.com/ilm/aqeedah/0038.htm | title=Types of Kufr (Disbelief) |accessdate=3 January 2016|publisher=SunnaOnline.com|author=Adapted from [[Ibn Kathir]]}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=January 2017}} there are eight kinds of ''Al-Kufr al-Akbar'' (major unbelief), some are the same as those described by Al-Hilali (''Kufr-al-I'rad'', ''Kufr-an-Nifaaq'') and some different.
# ''Kufrul-'Inaad'': Disbelief out of stubbornness. This applies to someone who knows the Truth and admits to knowing the Truth, and knowing it with his tongue, but refuses to accept it and refrains from making a declaration. God says: Throw into Hell every stubborn disbeliever.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ali|first=Abdullah Yusuf|title=The Qur'an|year=2001|publisher=Tahrike Tarsile Qur'an|id=verse 50:24}}</ref> # ''Kufrul-Inkaar'': Disbelief out of denial. This applies to someone who denies with both heart and tongue. God says: They recognize the favors of God, yet they deny them. Most of them are disbelievers.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ali|first=Abdullah Yusuf|title=The Qur'an|year=2001|publisher=Tahrike Tarsile Qur'an|id=verse 16:83}}</ref> # ''Kufrul-Juhood'': Disbelief out of rejection. This applies to someone who acknowledges the truth in his heart, but rejects it with his tongue. This type of kufr is applicable to those who call themselves Muslims but who reject any necessary and accepted norms of [[Islam]] such as [[Salaat]] and [[Zakat]]. God says: They denied them (our signs) even though their hearts believed in them, out of spite and arrogance.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ali|first=Abdullah Yusuf|title=The Qur'an|year=2001|publisher=Tahrike Tarsile Qur'an|id=verse 27:14}}</ref> # ''[[Munafiq|Kufrul-Nifaaq]]'': Disbelief out of hypocrisy. This applies to someone who pretends to be a believer but conceals his disbelief. Such a person is called a [[munafiq]] or hypocrite. God says: Verily the hypocrites will be in the lowest depths of Hell. You will find no one to help them.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ali|first=Abdullah Yusuf|title=The Qur'an|year=2001|publisher=Tahrike Tarsile Qur'an |id=verse 4:145}}</ref> # ''Kufrul-Kurh'': Disbelief out of detesting any of God's commands. God says: [[wikt:perdition|Perdition]] (destruction) has been consigned to those who disbelieve and He will render their actions void. This is because they are averse to that which God has revealed so He has made their actions fruitless.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ali|first=Abdullah Yusuf|title=The Qur'an|year=2001|publisher=Tahrike Tarsile Qur'an|id=verse 47:8–9}}</ref> # ''Kufrul-Istihzaha'': Disbelief due to mockery and derision. God says: Say: Was it at God, His signs and His [[apostle]]s that you were mocking? Make no excuses. You have disbelieved after you have believed.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ali|first=Abdullah Yusuf|title=The Qur'an|year=2001|publisher=Tahrike Tarsile Qur'an |id=verse 9:65–66}}</ref> # ''Kufrul-I'raadh'': Disbelief due to avoidance. This applies to those who turn away and avoid the truth. God says: And who is more unjust than he who is reminded of his Lord's signs but then turns away from them. Then he forgets what he has sent forward (for the Day of Judgement).<ref>{{cite book|last=Ali|first=Abdullah Yusuf|title=The Qur'an|year=2001|publisher=Tahrike Tarsile Qur'an|id=verse 18:57}}</ref> # ''Kufrul-Istibdaal'': Disbelief because of trying to substitute [[Sharia|God's Laws]] with man-made laws. God says: Or have they partners with God who have instituted for them a religion that God has not allowed.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ali|first=Abdullah Yusuf|title=The Qur'an|year=2001|publisher=Tahrike Tarsile Qur'an|id=verse 42:8}}</ref> God says: Say not concerning that which your tongues put forth falsely (that) is lawful and this is forbidden so as to invent a lie against God. Verily, those who invent a lie against God will never prosper.<ref>{{cite book|last=Ali|first=Abdullah Yusuf|title=The Qur'an|year=2001|publisher=Tahrike Tarsile Qur'an |id=verse 16:116}}</ref>
===Ignorance=== In Islam, [[jahiliyyah]] ("ignorance") refers to the time of [[Pre-Islamic Arabia|Arabia before Islam]]. It may also refer to modern secularist states.
==History of usage==
===In proper sense=== {{further|Islam and other religions}}
When the Islamic empire expanded, the word "''kafir''" was used broadly for all [[pagan]]s and anyone who disbelieved in Islam.<ref name=HMP/><ref name=HoI/> Historically, the attitude toward unbelievers in Islam was determined more by socio-political conditions than by religious doctrine.<ref name=EJBFEI-619/> A tolerance toward unbelievers "impossible to imagine in contemporary Christendom" prevailed even to the time of the [[Crusades]], particularly with respect to the People of the Book.<ref name=EJBFEI-619/> However, animosity was nourished by repeated wars with unbelievers, and warfare between [[Safavid]] Persia and [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman Turkey]] brought about application of the term ''kafir'' even to Persians in Turkish [[fatwa]]s.<ref name=EJBFEI-619/> During the era of European colonialism, the political decline of Islam impeded organized state action against the pressure from Western nations, and the resulting feeling of impotence contributed to a rise of hatred against unbelievers and its periodic manifestations, such as massacres.<ref name=EJBFEI-619/>
However, there was extensive [[religious violence in India]] between Muslims and non-Muslims during the [[Delhi Sultanate]] and [[Mughal Empire]] (before the political decline of Islam).<ref name=mgat>{{cite journal |last=Gaborieau |first=Marc |date=June 1985 |title=From Al-Beruni to Jinnah: Idiom, Ritual and Ideology of the Hindu-Muslim Confrontation in South Asia |journal=Anthropology Today |publisher=Royal Anthropological Institute of Great Britain and Ireland |volume=1 |issue=3 |pages=7–14 |doi=10.2307/3033123 |jstor=3033123}}</ref><ref>Holt et al., The Cambridge History of Islam - The Indian sub-continent, south-east Asia, Africa and the Muslim west, {{ISBN|978-0521291378}}</ref><ref>Scott Levi (2002), Hindu beyond Hindu Kush: Indians in Central Asian Slave Trade, Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society, Vol 12, Part 3, pp. 281–83</ref> In their memoirs on Muslim invasions, enslavement and plunder of this period, many Muslim historians in South Asia used the term Kafir for [[Hindu]]s, [[Buddhist]]s, [[Sikh]]s and [[Jain]]s.<ref name=HMP>{{cite journal |last=Engineer |first=Ashghar Ali |date=13–19 February 1999 |title=Hindu-Muslim Problem: An Approach |journal=Economic and Political Weekly |volume=37 |issue=7 |page=397 |doi=10.2307/4407649 |jstor=4407649}}</ref><ref name=HoI>Elliot and Dowson, [https://archive.org/stream/cu31924073036745#page/n285/mode/2up Tarikh-i Mubarak-Shahi], [[The History of India, as Told by Its Own Historians]] – The Muhammadan Period, Vol 4, Trubner London, p. 273</ref> <ref>Elliot and Dowson, [https://archive.org/stream/historyindiaast04elligoog#page/n363/mode/2up Tabakat-i-Nasiri], The History of India, as Told by Its Own Historians – The Muhammadan Period, Vol 2, Trubner London, pp. 347–67</ref><ref>Elliot and Dowson, [https://archive.org/stream/cu31924073036745#page/n81/mode/2up Tarikh-i Mubarak-Shahi], The History of India, as Told by Its Own Historians – The Muhammadan Period, Vol 4, Trubner London, pp. 68–69</ref> Raziuddin Aquil states that "non-Muslims were often condemned as ''kafirs'', in medieval Indian Islamic literature, including court chronicles, Sufi texts and literary compositions" and fatwas were issued that justified persecution of the non-Muslims.<ref>Raziuddin Aquil (2008), On Islam and Kufr in the Delhi Sultanate, in Rethinking a Millennium: Perspectives on Indian History (Editor: Rajat Datta), {{ISBN|978-8189833367}}, Chapter 7, pp. 168–85</ref>
Relations between [[Judaism|Jews]] and Muslims in the Arab world and use of the word "kafir" were equally as complex, and over the last century, issues regarding "kafir" have arisen over the conflict in [[Israel]] and [[Palestine (region)|Palestine]].<ref name="Taji-Farouki2000">{{cite journal |last=Taji-Farouki |first=Suha |date=October 2000 |title=Islamists and the Threat of Jihad: Hizb al-Tahrir and al-Muhajiroun on Israel and the Jews|journal=Middle Eastern Studies |volume=36 |issue=4 |page=26 |doi=10.1080/00263200008701330 |jstor=4284112}}</ref> Calling the Jews of Israel, "the usurping kafir", [[Yasser Arafat]] turned on the Muslim resistance and "allegedly set a precedent for preventing Muslims from mobilizing against 'aggressor disbelievers' in other Muslim lands, and enabled 'the cowardly, alien kafir' to achieve new levels of intervention in Muslim affairs."<ref name="Taji-Farouki2000" />
==== Muhammad's parents ====
A hadith in which Muhammad states that his father was in hell has become a source of disagreement about the status of Muhammad's parents. Over the centuries, Sunni scholars have dismissed this hadith despite its appearance in the authoritative ''[[Sahih Muslim]]'' collection. It passed through a single chain of transmission for three generations, so that its authenticity was not considered certain enough to supersede a theological consensus which stated that people who died before a prophetic message reached them—as Muhammad's father had done—could not be held accountable for not embracing it.<ref>{{Cite book|first=Jonathan A.C. |last=Brown| authorlink = Jonathan A.C. Brown | year=2015 | title=Misquoting Muhammad: The Challenge and Choices of Interpreting the Prophet's Legacy|publisher=Oneworld Publications (Kindle edition)|pages=Loc. 4042}}</ref> [[Shia Islam|Shia Muslims]] scholars likewise consider Muhammad's parents to be in Paradise.<ref>alhassanain. [http://www.alhassanain.com/english/book/book/beliefs_library/religions_and_sects/devils_deception_of_the_nasibi_wahabis/003.html The Nasibis Kufr Fatwa - that the Prophet (s)'sparents were Kaafir (God forbid)]</ref><ref>Shia Pen. [http://www.shiapen.com/comprehensive/non-egalitarian-imamate/monotheistic-lineage-prophets-imams.html Chapter Four – The pure monotheistic lineage of Prophets and Imams (as)]</ref> In contrast, the [[Salafi]]<ref>{{cite book|author=Richard Gauvain|title= Salafi Ritual Purity: In the Presence of God|ISBN=9780710313560|publisher=Routledge|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AJ6gL2iwhy8C&pg=PA335|page=335|year=2013}}</ref> website [[IslamQA.info]] argues that Islamic tradition teaches that Muhammad's parents were ''kuffār'' (disbelievers) who are in Hell.<ref>islamqa.info. [https://islamqa.info/en/47170 47170: Are the parents of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allaah be upon him) in Paradise or in Hell?]</ref>
===Other uses=== {{See also|Kaffir (racial term)|Kafiristan#Etymology}} [[File:011 Kafirs of Natal.jpg|thumb|''The Kafirs of Natal and the Zulu Country'' by Rev. Joseph Shooter]] By the 15th century, the word Kaffir was used by Muslims in Africa to refer to the non-Muslim African natives. Many of those ''kufari'' were [[Slavery|enslaved]] and sold by their Muslims captors to European and Asian merchants, mainly from Portugal, who by that time had established trading outposts along the coast of West Africa. These European traders adopted that Arabic word and its derivatives.<ref>{{cite book|last=Campo|first=Juan Eduardo|title=Encyclopedia of Islam|year=2009|publisher=Infobase Publishing|isbn=0-8160-5454-1 |page=422|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OZbyz_Hr-eIC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref>
Some of the earliest records of European usage of the word can be found in ''The Principal Navigations, Voyages, Traffiques and Discoveries of the English Nation'' by Hakluyt, Richard, 1552–1616.<ref>{{gutenberg author|id=Richard_Hakluyt | name=Richard Hakluyt}}</ref> In volume 4, Hakluyt writes: "calling them ''Cafars'' and ''Gawars'', which is, infidels or disbelievers.<ref>{{gutenberg|author=Richard Hakluyt|name=The Principal Navigations, Voyages, Traffiques and Discoveries of the English Nation – Volume 04|no=7769}}</ref> Volume 9 refers to the slaves (slaves called ''Cafari'') and inhabitants of Ethiopia (and they use to go in small shippes, and trade with the ''Cafars'') by two different but similar names. The word is also used in reference to the coast of Africa as ''land of Cafraria''.<ref>{{gutenberg|author=Richard Hakluyt|name=The Principal Navigations, Voyages, Traffiques and Discoveries of the English Nation – Volume 09|no=10673}}</ref> The 16th century explorer [[Leo Africanus]] described the ''Cafri'' as "[[negro]]es", and one of five principal population groups in Africa. He identified their geographical heartland as being located in remote southern Africa, an area which he designated as ''Cafraria''.<ref name="Leo5153">{{cite book|last1=Africanus|first1=Leo|title=The History and Description of Africa|date=1526|publisher=Hakluyt Society|pages=20, 53 & 65|url=https://archive.org/stream/historyanddescr03porygoog#page/n180/mode/2up|accessdate=27 July 2017}}</ref>
By the late 19th century the word was in use in English-language newspapers and books.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B02E2DD163DE433A25756C1A9609C94669ED7CF|title=Barnato a Suicide; The Kafir King Leaps Overboard....|year=1897|work=New York Times |accessdate=23 October 2008}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E00E6DB1F3DE633A2575BC1A9669D946497D6CF|title=Kafir Band in Jail and Mighty Glad, Too|date=1905-10-18|work=New York Times|accessdate=2008-10-23}}</ref><ref>{{gutenberg|no=20491|name=Kafir Stories| author=W. C. Scully}}</ref><ref>{{gutenberg|no=25277|name=The Right of American Slavery|author=T. W. Hoit}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://digital.library.upenn.edu/women/hsmith/autobiography/harry.html|title=The Autobiography of Lieutenant-General Sir Harry Smith|accessdate=23 October 2008}}</ref> One of the [[Union-Castle Line]] ships operating off the South African coast was named SS ''Kafir''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theshipslist.com/ships/lines/union.html|title=Union Steamship Company|accessdate=23 October 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922185140/http://www.theshipslist.com/ships/lines/union.html|archivedate=22 September 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In the early twentieth century, in his book ''The Essential Kafir'', Dudley Kidd writes that the word "''kafir''" had come to be used for all dark-skinned South African tribes. Thus, in many parts of South Africa, "''kafir''" became synonymous with the word, "native".<ref name="Kidd 1925 v">{{cite book|last=Kidd|first=Dudley|title=The Essential Kafir|year=1925|publisher=The MacMillan Company|location=New York|pages=v}}</ref> Currently in [[South Africa]], however, the word ''[[Kaffir (racial term)|kaffir]]'' is regarded as a racial slur, applied pejoratively or offensively to blacks.<ref>{{cite book|last=Theal|first=Georg McCall|title=Kaffir (Xhosa) Folk-Lore: A Selection from the Traditional Tales Current among the People Living on the Eastern Border of the Cape Colony with Copious Explanatory Notes|year=1970|publisher=Negro Universities|location=Westport, CT}}</ref>
The song "Kafir" by American technical death metal band [[Nile (band)|Nile]] from their sixth album ''[[Those Whom the Gods Detest]]'' uses as subject matter the violent attitudes that Muslim extremists have toward Kafirs.<ref>{{cite web|title=Song Lyrics|url=http://www.songlyrics.com/nile/kafir!-lyrics/|publisher=Sound Media; Tone Media|accessdate=4 December 2012}}</ref>
The [[Nuristani people]] were formally known as Kaffirs of [[Kafiristan]] before the [[Afghanistan|Afghan]] Islamization of the region. Moreover, their native name was Kapir, due to the lack of a "P" in Arabic, they coincidentally were called Kafirs, which was incorrect but again correct since they were [[polytheists]], moreover [[Henotheist]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nuristan, The Hidden Land of Hindu Kush, The Land of Light|url=http://knownuristan.blogspot.com/2012/06/nuristani-people.html|publisher=Blogger|accessdate=5 December 2012}}</ref>
The [[Kalash people|Kalash]] people located in the Hindu Kush mountain range south west of [[Chitral]] are known as Kafirs by the Muslim population of Chitral.<ref>{{cite web|last=Welker|first=Glenn|title=Kalash Kafirs of Chitral|url=http://www.indigenouspeople.net/Kalash%20Kafirs%20of%20Chitral.htm|publisher=Indigenous Peoples' Literature|accessdate=5 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120412035117/http://www.indigenouspeople.net/Kalash%20Kafirs%20of%20Chitral.htm|archivedate=12 April 2012|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
In modern Spanish, the word ''[[wikt:es:cafre|cafre]]'', derived from the Arabic ''kafir'' by way of Portuguese, also means "uncouth" or "savage".<ref>{{cite web|title=Collins Spanish Dictionary, entry for ''cafre''|url=http://www.wordreference.com/es/en/translation.asp?spen=cafre}}</ref>

page.title: List of Buddhist temples in Kyoto

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} There are 1,600 Buddhist temples scattered throughout the [[Kyoto Prefecture|prefecture of Kyoto]].<ref>Sacred Destinations: [http://www.sacred-destinations.com/japan/kyoto.htm Kyoto]</ref>
== Nara period in Kyoto (710-794) == {{dynamic list}} * {{Nihongo|[[Saihō-ji]]|西芳寺|''Saihō-ji''}}, also known as {{Nihongo|Koke-dera|苔寺|''Koke-dera''}} or {{Nihongo|Kōinzan Saihō-ji|洪隠山西芳寺|''Kōinzan Saihō-ji''}}.<ref>Kyoto: [http://www.pref.kyoto.jp/visitkyoto/en/theme/sites/shrines/w_heritage/11/ Saiho - ji.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308122724/http://www.pref.kyoto.jp/visitkyoto/en/theme/sites/shrines/w_heritage/11/ |date=8 March 2010 }}</ref> * [[Otagi Nenbutsu-ji|Otagi Nenbutsuji Temple]]
== Heian period in Kyoto (794-1229) == {{dynamic list}} * {{nihongo|[[Kōryū-ji]]|広隆寺|''Kōryū-ji''}}, also known as the {{nihongo|"Uzamasa-dera"|太秦寺|''Uzamasa-dera''}}.<ref name="pf110">Ponsonby-Fane, p. 110.</ref> * {{Nihongo|[[Rokkaku-dō (temple)|Rokkaku-dō]]|六角堂|''Rokkaku-dō''}}.<ref name="pf110"/> * {{Nihongo|[[Adashino Nenbutsu-ji]]|化野念仏寺|''Adashino Nenbutsu-ji''}}.<ref>Kyoto: [http://www.pref.kyoto.jp/visitkyoto/en/theme/sites/shrines/temples/m_adashino/ Adashino Nenbutsu-ji.]</ref> * {{Nihongo|[[Kiyomizu-dera]]|清水寺|''Kiyomizu-dera''}}, formally identified as {{nihongo|Otowa-san Kiyomizu-dera|音羽山清水寺|''Otowa-san Kiyomizu-dera''}}.<ref name="pf111">Ponsonby-Fane, p. 111.</ref> [http://www.city.kyoto.jp/bunshi/bunkazai/isan-d-e.htm  — World Historical Heritage Site] * {{nihongo|[[Enryaku-ji]]|延暦寺|''Enryaku-ji''}}.<ref name="pf111"/> [http://www.city.kyoto.jp/bunshi/bunkazai/isan-e-e.htm  — World Historical Heritage Site] * {{Nihongo|[[Yamashiro Kokubun-ji]]|山城国分寺|''Yamashiro Kokubun-ji}}.<ref name="pf111"/> * {{Nihongo|[[Tō-ji|East Temple]]|東寺|''[[Tō-ji]]''}}, formally identified as {{Nihongo|Kyō-ō-gokoku-ji|教王護国寺|''Kyō-ō-gokoku-ji''}}.<ref name="pf111"/> **{{Nihongo|[[Sai-ji|West Temple]]|西寺|''[[Sai-ji]]''}}, destroyed in 1233 and never rebuilt.<ref name="pf111"/> * {{nihongo|[[Daikaku-ji]]|大覚寺|''Daikaku-ji''}}.<ref name="pf112">Ponsonby-Fane, p. 112.</ref> * {{Nihongo|[[Ninna-ji]]|仁和寺|''Ninna-ji''}}.<ref name="pf112"/> [http://www.city.kyoto.jp/bunshi/bunkazai/isan-g-e.htm  — World Historical Heritage Site] * {{nihongo|[[Sennyū-ji]]|泉涌寺|''Sennyū-ji''}}.<ref name="pf113">Ponsonby-Fane, p. 113.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Gangyō-ji]]|元慶寺|''Gangyō-ji''}}, after 986 known more popularly as {{nihongo|Kazan-ji|花山寺|''[[Kazan-ji]]''}}.<ref name="pf113"/> * {{Nihongo|[[Rokushō-ji]]|六勝寺|''Rokushō-ji''}}.<ref name="pf114">Ponsonby-Fane, p. 114.</ref> **{{Nihongo|[[Hosshō-ji]]|法勝寺|''Hosshō-ji''}}.<ref name="takagaki2">Takagaki, Cary Shinji. (1999). [https://tspace.library.utoronto.ca/bitstream/1807/13266/1/NQ41322.pdf "The Rokusho-ji, the six superiority temples of Heian Japan," p. 2.]</ref> **{{Nihongo|[[Sonshō-ji]]|尊勝寺|''Sonshō-ji''}}.<ref name="pf114"/> **{{Nihongo|[[Saishō-ji]]|最勝寺|''Saishō-ji''}}.<ref name="takagaki2"/> **{{Nihongo|[[Enshō-ji (Antei)|Enshō-ji]]|円勝寺|''Enshō-ji]'}}.<ref name="takagaki2"/> **{{Nihongo|[[Jōshō-ji]]|成勝寺|''Jōshō-ji''}}.<ref name="takagaki2"/> **{{Nihongo|[[Enshō-ji (Kenchō)|Enshō-ji]]|延勝寺|''Enshō-ji''}}.<ref name="takagaki2"/> * {{nihongo|[[Daigo-ji]]|醍醐寺|''Daigo-ji''}}.<ref name="pf115">Ponsonby-Fane, p. 115.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Kajū-ji]]|勧修寺|''Kajū-ji''}}, also spelled Kwajū-ji.<ref name="pf115"/> * {{Nihongo|[[Nison-in]]|二村院|''Nison-in''}}, formally identified as {{Nihongo|Ogura-yama Nison-kyo-in Keidai-ji|小倉山 二尊教院 華台寺|''Ogura-yama Nison-kyo-in Keidai-ji''}}.<ref name="nisonin1">[http://yaccyann.sakura.ne.jp/nisonin/e.html Nisonin]</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Byōdō-in]]|平等院|''Byōdō-in''}}.<ref>Asian Historical Architecture: [http://www.orientalarchitecture.com/japan/kyoto/byodoin.php Byōdō-in.]</ref> * {{Nihongo|[[Sanjūsangen-dō]]|三十三間堂|''Sanjūsangen-dō''}}.<ref>Kyoto Travel: [http://www.kyoto.travel/place_to_go/rengeoin_temple_sanjusangendo.html Sanjūsangen-dō.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081223065624/http://www.kyoto.travel/place_to_go/rengeoin_temple_sanjusangendo.html |date=23 December 2008 }}</ref>
== Hōjō in the Kamakura period in Kyoto (1221-1333) == {{dynamic list}} * {{nihongo|[[Kennin-ji]]|建仁寺|''Kennin-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 150.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Tōfuku-ji]]|東福寺|''Tōfuku-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 152.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Nanzen-ji]]|南禅寺|''Nanzen-ji''}}, formerly {{nihongo|[[Eikan-dō Zenrin-ji]]|禅林寺|''Zenrin-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 154.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Daitoku-ji]]|大徳寺|''Daitoku-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 155.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Chion-in]]|知恩院|''Chion-in'' }}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 157.</ref> * [[Ryūhon-ji]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 159.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Bukkō-ji]]|佛光寺|''Bukkō-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 160.</ref> * [[Nishi Otani Betsuin]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 161.</ref>
== Ashikaga in the Kamakura period in Kyoto (1333-1582) == {{dynamic list}} * [[Tōjo-in]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 193.</ref> * [[Tōjo-ji]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 195.</ref> * {{Nihongo|[[Tenryū-ji]]|天龍寺|''Tenryū-ji''}}, formally identified as {{Nihongo|Tenryū Shiseizen-ji|天龍資聖禅寺|''Tenryū Shiseizen-ji''}};<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 197.</ref> formerly on same site in 9th century, {{Nihongo|Danrin-ji|檀林寺|''Danrin-ji''}} * {{Nihongo|[[Myōshin-ji]]|妙心寺|''Myōshin-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 198.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Shōkoku-ji]]|相国寺|''Shōkoku-ji''}}, formally identified as {{nihongo|Mannen-zan Shōkoku Shōten Zenji|| }}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 200.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Kinkaku-ji]]|金閣寺|''Kinkaku-ji''}} or the "Golden Pavilion Temple," formally identified as {{nihongo|[[Rokuon-ji]]|鹿苑寺|''Rokuon-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 203.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Ryōan-ji]]|竜安寺|''Ryōan-ji''}}.<ref>Moscher, Gouvernor. (1978). [https://books.google.com/books?id=DSisAAAACAAJ&dq=Kyoto:+A+Contemplative+Guide&client=firefox-a ''Kyoto: A Contemplative Guide,''] pp. 277-278.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Ginkaku-ji]]|銀閣寺|''Ginkaku-ji''}} or the "Temple of the Silver Pavilion," formally identified as {{nihongo|[[Jishō-ji]]|慈照寺|''Jishō-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 205.</ref>[http://www.city.kyoto.jp/bunshi/bunkazai/isan-n-e.htm  — World Historical Heritage Site] * [[Honkoku-ji]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 207.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Honnō-ji]]|本能寺|''Honnō-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 209.</ref>
== Azuchi-Momoyama period in Kyoto (1582-1615) == {{dynamic list}} * [[Hompa Hongwan-ji]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 270.</ref> * [[Ōtaniha Hongwan-ji]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 283.</ref> * {{nihongo| [[Hōkō-ji (Kyoto)|Hōkō-ji]]|方広寺|''Hōkō-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 290.</ref> * [[Mimizuka]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 296.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Kōdai-ji]]|高台寺|''Kōdai-ji''}}, formally identified as {{nihongo|Jubuzan Kōdai-ji|鷲峰山高台寺|''Jubuzan Kōdai-ji''}}.<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 297.</ref> * [[Sambō-in]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 301.</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Nishi Hongan-ji]]|西本願寺|''Nishi Hongan-ji''}}.<ref>Asian Historical Architecture: [http://www.orientalarchitecture.com/japan/kyoto/nishi.php Nishi Hongan-ji.]</ref> * {{nihongo|[[Higashi Hongan-ji]]|東本願寺|''Higashi Hongan-ji''}}.<ref>Asian Historical Architecture: [http://www.orientalarchitecture.com/japan/kyoto/higashi.php Higashi Hongan-ji.]</ref>
== Edo period in Kyoto (1615-1869) == {{dynamic list}} * [[Shōgo-in]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 393.</ref> * [[Chishaku-in]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 395.</ref> * [[Reikan-ji]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 398.</ref> * [[Reigen-ji]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 399.</ref> * [[Yentsū-ji]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 400.</ref> * [[Rinkyū-ji]].<ref>Ponsonby-Fane, p. 401.</ref>
==See also== * [[List of Shinto shrines in Kyoto]] *[[Thirteen Buddhist Sites of Kyoto]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|3}}
==References== * Moscher, Gouvernor. (1978). [https://books.google.com/books?id=DSisAAAACAAJ&dq=kyoto+a+contemplative+guide+japan+moscher&lr=&client=firefox-a ''Kyoto: A Contemplative Guide.''] Tokyo: [[Tuttle Publishing]]. {{ISBN|978-0-8048-1294-8}} * Ponsonby-Fane, Richard Arthur Brabazon. (1956). [https://books.google.com/books?id=OpOdHQAACAAJ&dq=Kyoto:+The+Old+Capital+of+Japan,+794-1869&client=firefox-a ''Kyoto: The Old Capital of Japan, 794-1869.''] Kyoto: The Ponsonby Memorial Society. [http://www.worldcat.org/wcpa/oclc/36644 OCLC 36644] * Iwao, Seiichi, Teizō Iyanaga, Susumu Ishii, Shōichirō Yoshida, ''et al.'' (2002). [https://books.google.com/books?id=fW9v37poqcQC&client=firefox-a ''Dictionnaire historique du Japon.''] Paris: Maisonneuve & Larose. {{ISBN|978-2-7068-1632-1}}; [http://www.worldcat.org/wcpa/isbn/2706816325 OCLC 51096469] * [[Donald Richie|Richie, Donald]]. (1995). [https://books.google.com/books?id=spx_ZljTPn4C&dq=ryoan-ji&lr=&client=firefox-a&source=gbs_summary_s&cad=0 ''The Temples of Kyoto.''] Tokyo: Tuttle Publishing. {{ISBN|978-0-8048-2032-5}}
==External links== * [http://www.gojapango.com/travel/kyoto_temple.htm Kyoto Temples] Alphabetical listing for Kyoto Prefecture (127 as of 8 December 2012) * [http://www.taleofgenji.org/japanese_temples_shrines.html#kyotocity Photos of temples, shrines and gardens in Kyoto] Alphabetical listing of attractions, but includes at least 114 Temples in Kyoto Prefecture (as of 8 December 2012)
{{Buddhist temples in Japan}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Buddhist Temples In Kyoto}} [[Category:Buddhist temples in Kyoto| ]] [[Category:Lists of Buddhist temples|Kyoto]] [[Category:Lists of buildings and structures in Japan by prefecture|Kyoto, Buddhist temples]] [[Category:Lists of religious buildings and structures in Japan]]

revision.text:
==[[Torah]]==
===[[Book of Genesis|Genesis]]=== * [[Genesis creation myth|Creation]] * [[Adam and Eve]] (covers creation and fall of man) * [[Fall (religion)|The Fall of Man]] * [[Cain and Abel]] * [[Generations of Adam|Adam's descendants]] * [[Nephilim|The Nephilim]] * [[Noah and the flood]] * [[Noah's Covenant|The Covenant of Noah]] * [[Ham, son of Noah|The Curse of Ham]] * [[Sons of Noah]] * [[Tower of Babel|The tower of Babel]] * Abram's migration * [[A wife confused for a sister]] (featuring Abraham, Sarah, and Pharaoh, as characters) * [[Abraham and Lot's conflict]] * [[Chedorlaomer]] * Abraham and Melchizedek * [[Abram's Covenant|The Covenant of Abram]] * [[Hagar|Hagar and Ishmael]] * [[Ishmael|The first circumcision]] * [[Sodom and Gomorrah]] * [[Lot's drunkenness]] * [[Cave of the Patriarchs|The cave of Machpelah]] * [[A wife confused for a sister]] (featuring Abraham, Sarah, and Abimelech, as characters) * [[Binding of Isaac|The Binding of Isaac]] * [[Keturah|Keturah's sons]] * [[Isaac and Rebekah]] * [[Jacob and Esau]] * [[Isaac's Covenant|The Covenant of Isaac]] * [[A wife confused for a sister]] (featuring Isaac, Rebekah, and Abimelech, as characters) * The [[blessing of Isaac]] * [[Jacob's exile|The exile of Jacob]] * [[Jacob's Ladder (Bible)|Jacob's Ladder]] * [[Jacob and Rachel|Jacob and Rachel/The sheep and the stone]] * [[Rachel and Leah]] * [[Jacob's children]] * [[The blemished flock]] * [[The stones of Galeed]] * [[Jacob's gifts to Esau]] * [[Jacob wrestling with the angel]] * [[Jacob's reconciliation with Esau]] * [[Rape of Dinah|The rape of Dinah]] * [[The birth of Benjamin]] * [[Reuben and Bilhah]] * [[The list of Edomite Kings]] * [[Joseph enslaved]] * [[Tamar (Genesis)#Tamar and Judah|Tamar and Judah]] * [[Potiphar's wife]] * [[The butler and the baker]] * [[Pharaoh's Dreams]] * [[Joseph and his brothers]] * [[Israel's migration]] * [[Ephraim's pre-eminence]] * The [[blessing of Jacob]] * [[The burial of Jacob]] * [[The death of Joseph's generation]]
===Exodus=== {{main article|Book of Exodus}}
* [[The Hebrew midwives]] * [[Moses' exile]] * The [[Burning Bush]] * The [[Signs of Moses]] * [[Zipporah at the inn]] * [[Go Down Moses|Let my people go]] * [[Bricks without straw]] * [[With a strong hand and an outstretched arm]] * [[Aaron's rod#Biblical references|Aaron's rod becomes a serpent]] * The [[Plagues of Egypt]] * The [[Passover]] * [[The Exodus]]<!-- should be a different article to Exodus which discusses the whole book--> * [[Passage of the Red Sea]] * The [[Song of the sea]] * [[Meribah#Events|Massah U-Meribah]] * [[Amalek]] * [[Jethro (Bible)|Jethro]] * [[Encamping at Sinai]] * [[Ethical Decalogue|The Ten Commandments (first set)]] * The [[Covenant Code]] * [[The Golden Calf]] * [[Ritual Decalogue|The Ten Commandments (second set)]] * [[Construction of the Tabernacle]] Exodus 35-40
===Leviticus=== {{main article|Leviticus}} * The [[Priestly Code]] * The [[Holiness Code]] * The Ordination of Aaron and His Sons * The Death of [[Nadab and Abihu]] ([http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Leviticus%2010&version=NASB Leviticus 10:1-20]) * A Blasphemer Stoned ([http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Leviticus%2024:10-23&version=NASB Leviticus 24:10-23])
===Numbers=== {{main article|Book of Numbers}}
* The [[Israelite Census]] * [[Departing Sinai]] * The [[shower of quails]] * [[Snow-white Miriam#Snow-white Miriam|Snow-white Miriam]] * [[The Twelve Spies|The report of the spies]] * [[Korah, Dathan and Abiram]] * [[Aaron's rod#Biblical references|Aaron's rod sprouts and bears fruit]] * [[Meribah#Events|Waters of Meribah]] * [[The short route to Canaan]] * Lifting up of the brass serpent ([[Nehushtan]]) * [[The conquest of the eastern route]] * [[Balaam|Balaam and the Donkey]] * The [[Heresy of Peor]] * [[The appointment of Joshua]] * The [[Midian War|War against the Midianites]]. * [[Transjordan (Bible)|Machir, Reuben, and Gad, in Gilead and Jazeer]] * [[The distribution of Canaan]]
===[[Deuteronomy]]=== * Moses Begins to Retell Wilderness Stories, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Deuteronomy%201-3&version=NASB Deuteronomy 1-3] * The [[Deuteronomic Code]] * The [[Song of Moses]], [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Deuteronomy%2032&version=NASB Deuteronomy 32] * The [[Blessing of Moses]], [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Deuteronomy+33&version=NASB Deuteronomy 33] * The [[Moses#Death|Death of Moses]], [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Deuteronomy+34&version=NASB Deuteronomy 34]
==[[Nevi'im]]==
===[[Book of Joshua|Joshua]]=== * Charge from God to Joshua. Joshua takes charge, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Joshua+1&version=NASB 1:1-18] * [[Rahab|Rahab and the Spies]] * [[The Fall of Jericho]] * [[The Sun Stands Still]]
===[[Book of Judges|Judges]]===
* Israel Disobeys God, 2:1-23 ''' Othniel '''
* [[Othniel]]'s Campaign as Judge, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Judges%203:7-11&version=NASB 3:7-11]
''' Ehud '''
* [[Ehud]] gains the victory over Moabite King [[Eglon (king)|Eglon]] [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Judges%203:12-30&version=NASB 3:12-30]
''' Shamgar '''
3:31
''' Deborah '''
* [[Deborah]], [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Judges+4&version=NASB 4:1-24] * The Song of Deborah, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Judges+5&version=NASB 5:1-31]
''' Gideon '''
* The Lord Appears to [[Gideon]], 6:1-40 * The Sign of the Fleece and Gideon's Three Hundred, 7:1-25 * [[Midian]] Subdued, 8:1-35
''' Abimelech '''
* [[Abimelech (Judges)|Abmilech]], son of Gideon (Jerubbaal) made king at [[Shechem]] after destroying his own family, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Judges%209:1-6&version=NASB 9:1-6] * [[Jotham]], the lone survivor and brother, tells The Parable of the Trees. He speaks against Abimelech then flees, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Judges%209:7-21&version=NASB 9:7-21] * Shechem betrays Abimelech. He attacks and destroys the city. * Abimelech captures the town of [[Thebez]], but he is [[Woman of Thebez|mortally wounded by a woman]]. [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Judges%209:22-57&version=NASB 9:22-57]
''' Tola '''
*Tola the son of Puah, the son of Dodo, a man of Issachar dwelt in Shamir in mount Ephraim. He judged Israel for twenty-three years, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Judges%2010:1-2&version=NASB 10:1,2]
''' Jair '''
''' Jephthah '''
* Jephthah and His Vow, 11: 1-40
''' Ibzah '''
12:8-10
''' Elon '''
12:11, 12
''' Abdon '''
12:13-15
''' [[Samson]] '''
* The Birth of Samson, 13:1-25 * Samson's Phlistine Wife, 14:1-20 * The Philistine's Defeated, 15: 1-20 * [[Delilah|Samson and Delilah]], 16:1-31 * The Death of Samson, 17:1-13
''' Other Stories '''
* [[Micah's Idol]]atry, 18: 1-31 * The Levite's Concubine and Gibeah's Crime, 19:1-30 * [[Battle of Gibeah]]. War with the Benjamites, 20:1-48 * Wives for the Benjamites, 21:1-25
===[[Books of Samuel|1 & 2 Samuel]]===
* [[Samuel (Bible)|Hannah and the Birth of Samuel]] * [[David|David and Goliath]] * [[David and Jonathan]] * [[David and Bathsheba]] * [[Absalom|Absalom's Conspiracy]]
===[[Books of Kings|1 & 2 Kings]]===
* [[Solomon|The Wisdom of Solomon]] * [[Solomon's Temple|Solomon builds the Temple]] * [[The Queen of Sheba]] * [[Elijah|Elijah on Mount Carmel]] * [[Elijah|Elijah Taken up to Heaven]] * [[The Sunnamite's Son]] * [[Naaman|The Healing of Naaman]] * [[Hezekiah]]
===Isaiah===
===[[Book of Jeremiah|Jeremiah]]=== * [[Jeremiah#Jeremiah's calling|Call of Jeremiah]], [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=jeremiah%201:1-10&version=NASB 1:1-10] * Jeremiah sees an almond rod then a boiling pot, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah%201:11-19&version=NASB 1:11-19] * Jeremiah's message at the temple gate, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+7&version=NASB 7:1-34] * Jeremiah buys a linen waistband and puts it in the crevice of a rock near the Euphrates. [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah%2013:1-11&version=NASB 13:1-11] * The LORD tells Jeremiah that he can't get married or have children, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+16&version=NASB 16:1-21] * Jeremiah stands at the city gate proclaiming the Sabbath's importance [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah%2017:19-27&version=NASB 17:19-27] * Jeremiah visits the potter, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah%2017:19-27&version=NASB 18:1-23] * Jeremiah takes a potter's clay jar and some of the elders to the valley of Ben-hinnon, [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+19&version=NASB#en-NASB-19414 19:1-15] * Pashur, the chief officer in the house of the LORD, beats Jeremiah and puts him in stocks. Jeremiah's complains to God. [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+20&version=NASB 20:1-18] * Zedekiah, Pashur, and Zephaniah ask Jeremiah if there is a positive message from the LORD. Jeremiah prophesies doom for them. He predicts the coming of the Branch. [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah%2021-23&version=NASB 21:1-23:40] * Jeremiah summarizes 23 years of prophetic ministry; lists the nations under judgment and predicts 70 years of captivity. [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+25&version=NASB 25:1-38] * Jeremiah prophesies against the temple and the city. He is accused of a capital crime. His life is spared after discussion of precedence. Thanks to Ahikam the son of Shaphan. [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+26&version=NASB#en-NASB-19597 26:1-24] * Following the LORD's directive, Jeremiah puts himself in bonds and a yoke. He relates that the LORD has given Nebuchadnezzar the land until his time comes. Hananiah breaks Jeremiah's yoke and prophesies the opposite message. [http://www.biblegateway.com/passage/?search=Jeremiah+27&version=NASB 27:1-22] * [[Babylonian captivity|The Exile]]
===Ezekiel===
===Hosea===
Hosea was a prophet who lived and prophesied just before the destruction of Israel in 722 BC. He preached to the northern kingdom. Throughout the book you will see that he refers to Israel and Ephraim. Ephraim was the largest tribe in Israel and sometimes the whole nation was referred to as Ephraim.

/* List of all registered New Testament uncial codices */
revision.text:
[[File:Codex Sinaiticus-small.jpg|thumb|right|240px|[[Codex Sinaiticus]], [[Gospel of Matthew|Matthew]] 6:9-10]] [[File:Codex Alexandrinus J 1,1-7.PNG|thumb|right|240px|[[Codex Alexandrinus]], [[Gospel of John|John]] 1:1–7]] A '''New Testament uncial''' is a section of the New Testament in [[Greek language|Greek]] or [[Latin language|Latin]] [[majuscule]] letters, written on [[parchment]] or [[vellum]]. This style of writing is called ''Biblical Uncial'' or ''Biblical Majuscule''. New Testament uncials are distinct from other ancient texts based on the following differences: * [[List of New Testament papyri|New Testament papyri]] – written on [[papyrus]] and generally more ancient * [[List of New Testament minuscules|New Testament minuscules]] – written in [[Minuscule cursive|minuscule]] letters and generally more recent * [[List of New Testament lectionaries|New Testament lectionaries]] – usually written minuscule (but some in uncial) letters and generally more recent * New Testament uncials – written in majuscule letters, on parchment or velum. == Classification of uncials == In 1751, New Testament theologian [[Johann Jakob Wettstein]] knew of only 23 uncial [[codex|codices]] of the New Testament.{{cite book | last = Wettstein | first = J. J. | authorlink = Johann Jakob Wettstein | title = Novum Testamentum Graecum editionis receptae cum lectionibus variantibus codicum manuscripts | publisher = Ex Officina Dommeriana | year = 1751 | location = Amsterdam | pages = 8–41 | url = https://archive.org/stream/hekainediatheken00clem#page/8/mode/2up | isbn = }} By 1859, [[Constantin von Tischendorf]] had increased that number to 64 uncials, and in 1909 [[Caspar René Gregory]] enumerated 161 uncial codices. By 1963, [[Kurt Aland]], in his ''Kurzgefasste Liste'', had enumerated 250, then in 1989, finally, 299 uncials. Wettstein inaugurated the modern method of classification. He used capital Latin letters to identify the uncials. Codex Alexandrinus received the letter "A", Codex Vaticanus – "B", Codex Ephraemi – "C", Codex Bezae – "D", until he arrived at the last letter used by him, "O". Succeeding generations used this pattern, but newly discovered manuscripts soon exhausted the Latin alphabet.{{Cite book |last=Aland |first=Kurt |authorlink=Kurt Aland | last2 = Aland | first2 = Barbara | authorlink2 = Barbara Aland | others = Erroll F. Rhodes (trans.) |title=The Text of the New Testament: An Introduction to the Critical Editions and to the Theory and Practice of Modern Textual Criticism |publisher=[[William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company]] |year=1995 |place=Grand Rapids |pages=72–73, 104, 106 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2pYDsAhUOxAC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-0-8028-4098-1}} As a result, letters of the Greek and Hebrew alphabets began to be used. Tischendorf, for example, assigned the [[Codex Sinaiticus]] the Hebrew letter א. [[Uncial 047]] received [[siglum]] ב1, [[Codex Vaticanus 2061|Uncial 048]] received ב2, [[Uncial 075]] received ג, [[Codex Macedoniensis]] – ו, to name a few.H. Schumacher, ''A Handbook of Scripture Study'' (B. Herder Book Co.: St. Louis-London 1923), p. 28.{{cite book|last=Gregory|first=Caspar René|authorlink=Caspar René Gregory|title=Die griechischen Handschriften des Neuen Testament|url=https://archive.org/stream/diegriechischen00greggoog#page/n183/mode/2up|year=1908|publisher=J. C. Hinrichs'sche Buchhandlung|location=Leipzig|pages=172–175}} When Greek and Hebrew letters ran out, Gregory assigned uncials numerals with an initial 0 (to distinguish them from the symbols of minuscule manuscripts). Codex Sinaiticus received the number 01, Alexandrinus – 02, Vaticanus – 03, Ephraemi – 04, etc. The last uncial manuscript known by Gregory received number 0161.[[C. R. Gregory]], [https://archive.org/stream/diegriechischen00greggoog#page/n55/mode/2up ''Die griechischen Handschriften des Neuen Testament''] (Leipzig 1908), p. 44. [[Ernst von Dobschütz]] expanded the list of uncials through 0208 in 1933.{{Cite book |last=Aland |first=Kurt |authorlink=Kurt Aland | last2 = Aland | first2 = Barbara | authorlink2 = Barbara Aland | others = Erroll F. Rhodes (trans.) |title=The Text of the New Testament: An Introduction to the Critical Editions and to the Theory and Practice of Modern Textual Criticism |publisher=[[William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company]] |year=1995 |place=Grand Rapids |page=74 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2pYDsAhUOxAC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-0-8028-4098-1}} {{as of|2012}} over 320 sigla for uncial codices have been catalogued by the [[Institute for New Testament Textual Research|Institute for New Testament Textual Research (INTF)]] in Münster, Germany.{{Cite web|url=http://intf.uni-muenster.de/vmr/NTVMR/ListeHandschriften.php|title=Liste Handschriften|publisher=Institute for New Testament Textual Research|accessdate=16 November 2010|location=Münster}}[[Eberhard Nestle]], [[Erwin Nestle]], Barbara Aland and [[Kurt Aland]] (eds), ''[[Novum Testamentum Graece]]'', 27th edition, (Stuttgart: ''[[Deutsche Bibelgesellschaft]]'', 2001). However, the 322 currently catalogued does not provide a precise count of all the New Testament Greek uncials. [[Uncial 0168]] has been lost and over thirty manuscripts are associated with a smaller set of designations.074, 084, 090, 0110, 0112, 0113, 0117, 0119, 0123, 0124, 0125, 0137, 0138, 0139, 0149, 0179, 0180, 0190, 0191, 0193, 0194, 0195, 0202, 0215, 0224, 0235, 0285, 0293. Sometimes one number also applies to two separate manuscripts, as with uncial 092a and 092b, 0121a and 0121b, and 0278a and 0278b. Some other numerical designations should be reallocated to other lists: 055 (commentary), 0100 (lectionary), 0129 (lectionary), 0152 ([[Amulet|talisman]]), 0153 ([[ostracon]]), 0192 (lectionary), 0195 (lectionary), 0203 (lectionary).{{Elucidate|date=May 2012}}{{Cite book |last=Aland |first=Kurt |authorlink=Kurt Aland | last2 = Aland | first2 = Barbara | authorlink2 = Barbara Aland | others = Erroll F. Rhodes (trans.) |title=The Text of the New Testament: An Introduction to the Critical Editions and to the Theory and Practice of Modern Textual Criticism |publisher=[[William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company]] |year=1995 |place=Grand Rapids |page=106 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2pYDsAhUOxAC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-0-8028-4098-1}} Uncial 0212 from the 3rd or 4th century is more properly a witness to the [[Diatessaron]] than to the New Testament itself.{{Cite book |last=Aland |first=Kurt |authorlink=Kurt Aland | last2 = Aland | first2 = Barbara | authorlink2 = Barbara Aland | others = Erroll F. Rhodes (trans.) |title=The Text of the New Testament: An Introduction to the Critical Editions and to the Theory and Practice of Modern Textual Criticism |publisher=[[William B. Eerdmans Publishing Company]] |year=1995 |place=Grand Rapids |page=104 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2pYDsAhUOxAC&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_ge_summary_r&cad=0#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-0-8028-4098-1}} So, the number 322 is merely nominal; the actual figure should be somewhat lower.J. K. Elliott, "The citation of manuscripts In recent printed editions of the Greek New Testament", ''Novum Testamentum'' XXV, 2 (1983), pp. 103–104; T. Wassermann, "Some Bibliographic Notes on Greek New Testament Manuscripts", ''Novum Testamentum'' 49 (2007), pp. 291–295. Conversely, [[minuscule 1143]], known as ''Beratinus 2'', has some parts that were written in [[Uncial script#Half-uncial|semi-uncial]] letters. == List of all registered New Testament uncial codices == * The numbers (#) are the now standard system of [[Biblical manuscripts#Gregory-Aland|Gregory-Aland]]. * Dates are estimated [[Palaeography|palaeographically]] by the INTF (except [[Codex Vaticanus 354]] where the scribe gave a date — 949). * Content generally only describes sections of the New Testament: [[Gospel]]s (Gosp), The [[Acts of the Apostles]] (Acts), [[Pauline Epistles]] (Paul), [[Catholic epistles]] (CE), and so on. Sometimes the surviving portion of a codex is so limited that specific books, chapters or even verses can be indicated. Linked articles, where they exist, generally specify content in detail, by verse. * Digital images are referenced with direct links to the hosting web pages, with the exception of those at the [[INTF]]. The quality and accessibility of the images is as follows: {| style="background:transparent" |bgcolor="sandybrown"|Gold color indicates high resolution color images available online. |- |bgcolor="tan"|Tan color indicates high resolution color images available locally, not online. |- |bgcolor="wheat"|Light tan color indicates only a small fraction of manuscript pages with color images available online. |- |bgcolor="lightgray"|Light gray color indicates black/white or microfilm images available online. |- |bgcolor="powderblue"|Light blue color indicates manuscript not imaged, and is currently lost or ownership unknown. |- |bgcolor="mistyrose"|Light pink color indicates manuscript destroyed, presumed destroyed, or deemed too fragile to digitize. |- |bgcolor="violet"|Violet color indicates high resolution ultraviolet images available online. |}
† Indicates the manuscript has damaged or missing pages.
K Indicates manuscript also includes a commentary.
[ ] Brackets around Gregory-Aland number indicate the manuscript belongs to an already numbered manuscript, was found to not be a continuous text manuscript, is destroyed or presumed destroyed. Only one uncial, [[Codex Sinaiticus]] has a complete text of the [[New Testament]]. [[Codex Alexandrinus]] has an almost complete text. It contains all books of the New Testament but lacks some leaves of Matthew (25), John (2), and Second Corinthians (3). [[Codex Vaticanus Graecus 1209|Codex Vaticanus]] lacks the four last books, and the [[Epistle to the Hebrews]] is not complete. Codex Ephraemi has approximately 66 per cent of the New Testament. Uncials with designations higher than 046 typically have only one or two leaves. === Uncials with sigla === The first 45 uncials have been assigned descriptive names as well as a single letter code called a ''[[siglum]]'', for usage in academic writing. Beginning with uncial 046 the assignment of ''sigla'' was dropped and only a few manuscripts thereafter received a descriptive name. {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center" |- !#!!Sign!!Name!!Date!!Content!!Pages!!Institution!!City!!Country!!ImagesThe two primary collections of manuscript images include the CSNTM ( {{cite web|url=http://www.csntm.org/Manuscript | title=Manuscript Search|publisher=Center for the Student of New Testament Manuscripts |accessdate=2016-08-26}}) and the INTF ( {{cite web|url=http://ntvmr.uni-muenster.de/manuscript-workspace/| title=Manuscript Workspace|publisher=''Institut für Neutestamentliche Textforschung''|accessdate=2016-08-26}}) Other hosted images are referenced separately. |- |rowspan=3| 01 |rowspan=3| {{lang|he|א}} |rowspan=3| [[Codex Sinaiticus|Sinaiticus]] |rowspan=3| 4th |rowspan=3| [[New Testament]] |rowspan=3| 148 |rowspan=3| [[British Library]], Add. 43725 |rowspan=3| London |rowspan=3| United Kingdom |bgcolor="sandybrown"|[[Codex Sinaiticus|CS]],{{cite web|url=http://codexsinaiticus.org/en/manuscript.aspx| title=Codex Sinaiticus|publisher=British Library, Leipzig University Library, St Catherine's Monastery at Sinai and the National Library of Russia.|accessdate=2017-07-07}} INTF |- |bgcolor="sandybrown"|[[British Library|BL]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bl.uk/manuscripts/FullDisplay.aspx?ref=Add_MS_43725| title=Add MS 43725|publisher=British Library|accessdate=2017-07-07}} |- |bgcolor="lightgray"|[http://www.csntm.org/Manuscript/View/GA_01 CSNTM] |- |rowspan=2| 02 |rowspan=2| A |rowspan=2| [[Codex Alexandrinus|Alexandrinus]] |rowspan=2| 5th |rowspan=2| [[New Testament]]† |rowspan=2| 144 |rowspan=2| [[British Library]], Royal 1 D.
